[{'created': '2012-06-27 00:30:51.000000000', 'message': 'Updated wording for instance termination.

This better reflects the fact that termination is not an
immediate action and may not complete instantly (or ever...)

Change-Id: I44fd2efcbe8d16f7816ec190ff8fbf45a66dd16e
'}]
commit_message:
Updated wording for instance termination.

This better reflects the fact that termination is not an
immediate action and may not complete instantly (or ever...)

Change-Id: I44fd2efcbe8d16f7816ec190ff8fbf45a66dd16e

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-23 21:03:33.000000000', 'message': 'Volume Progress Bar & Fixes For Quota

When a volume creation exceed the allocation quota
a vague error message was returned that offered the
user no guidance as to what went wrong. This has
been fixed.

Fixes Bug #1012883

This change also abstracts the Quota javascript to
allow it to be used anywhere on the site for any
progress bars that are to be shown in the future.

Implements blueprint progress-bar-javascript

On top of this I have renamed all "can_haz" filters
in the code, as they are really sort of embarassing.

Lastly, I have added the ability to append JS
events to the window load when a modal is loaded as
a static page, OR when it is loaded as an AJAX
modal.

Change-Id: I4b0cefa160cafbbd07d4b0981f62febaed051871

commit_message:
Volume Progress Bar & Fixes For Quota

When a volume creation exceed the allocation quota
a vague error message was returned that offered the
user no guidance as to what went wrong. This has
been fixed.

Fixes Bug #1012883

This change also abstracts the Quota javascript to
allow it to be used anywhere on the site for any
progress bars that are to be shown in the future.

Implements blueprint progress-bar-javascript

On top of this I have renamed all "can_haz" filters
in the code, as they are really sort of embarassing.

Lastly, I have added the ability to append JS
events to the window load when a modal is loaded as
a static page, OR when it is loaded as an AJAX
modal.

Change-Id: I4b0cefa160cafbbd07d4b0981f62febaed051871

commit_message:
Fixes bug 1014194, metadata keys are incorrect for kernel-id and ramdisk-id

Kernel and ramdisk IDs are using currently being inserted in the metadata
using the keys aki-id and ari-id. They should be using the keys kernel-id
and ramdisk-id.
http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/instancedata-data-categories.html

This bug is in a block of code which did not previously have test coverage;
this change also adds that coverage.

Change-Id: I2ee3663169160c0e351e548d831fef2f34f9f2fd

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-28 21:34:30.000000000', 'message': 'Retry against different Glance hosts.

Patch to refactor Dom0 plugins introduced a bug where the same Glance
server would be selected on each retry. This patch introduces a callback
which lets the retry function choose a new Glance server on each pass.

Fixes bug 1019032

Change-Id: I6bac88a913ab19311671d8de7c9cc8f248928b2c
'}]
commit_message:
Retry against different Glance hosts.

Patch to refactor Dom0 plugins introduced a bug where the same Glance
server would be selected on each retry. This patch introduces a callback
which lets the retry function choose a new Glance server on each pass.

Fixes bug 1019032

Change-Id: I6bac88a913ab19311671d8de7c9cc8f248928b2c

commit_message:
Align run_tests.py pep8 with tox.

tox uses pep8 1.1, but tools/test-requires was set to pep8 1.2.
This sets pep8 back to 1.1

Change-Id: I63612d84a245def20367e192f1dda88aff061cbc

commit_message:
Keystone should use openstack.common.jsonutils

Implements blueprint use-common-jsonutils

1. Edit openstack-common.conf and import keystone/openstack/common/jsonutils.py
2. Remove json package imports and replace with jsonutils

Client code in vendor/ hasn't been changed

Change-Id: I57c670fde9f2c2241eddab1b012e8d5e6a72deb7

commit_message:
Refactor Dom0 Glance plugin.

Moves shareable code out to a new utils file where future Dom0 plugins
can make use of it.

Change-Id: I57eb20b4ca308fdda424599d36d94f120d99ec0d

subject: Add multi-process support for API services
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 1, 'name': 'James E. Blair', 'email': 'jim@acmegating.com', 'username': 'corvus'}, {'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 209, 'name': 'Josh Kearney', 'email': 'josh@jk0.org', 'username': 'jk0'}, {'_account_id': 475, 'name': 'Rick Harris', 'email': 'rick.harris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'rconradharris'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 1849, 'name': 'Joe Gordon', 'email': 'joe.gordon0@gmail.com', 'username': 'jogo'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-26 21:50:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-06-26 21:51:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I am a fan. Awesome work. Curious about what others might think before +2ing.

Way to go Johannes, YAY! \o/'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-26 21:54:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-06-26 23:23:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Looks nice.

One thing I didn't like when I looked at the initial version is that I feel that 'SIGTERM' should always cause a graceful shutdown... It doesn't serve much purpose as an immediate shutdown since SIGKILLing everything is (almost) the same behavior.  I generally think of SIGHUP for things like config reload.

Maybe my experience is not the norm.. I have no idea.  Either way, I'm not sure of better signal names to use... and I think this matches glance behavior."}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2012-06-27 00:29:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Do not merge

Hi, this patch took out a Jenkins slave while running the unit tests:

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/1080/console

and caused the slave to swap so badly that it paged the rackspace cloud ops.  If you upload another patchset that behaves similarly, or approve this patch, the same thing will happen again.

At this point, I do not know whether there is a bug in the code (there are very weird errors in that console log), or merely that our build slaves need more memory to test this kind of change.  Any analysis that you can do independently would be welcome, and if we really need to upgrade the size of the build slaves, we will.  They currently have 2G of RAM, which is usually quite sufficient to run unit tests.

We also need to protect the Jenkins slaves from changes that exceed their capacity; we will start working on that.

If you can hold off on uploading a new patchset to this change, or approving it, for a short while, that would be greatly appreciated.  Feel free to chat with mtaylor or jeblair in IRC about this.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-06-27 00:41:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Test failed for me as well.  Spawned 33 separate python processes and went  of control"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-27 01:26:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

It works fine for me on my development environment. It has 2GB of RAM too, but it should be fine even with 1GB.

Ugh, it's going to be hard to troubleshoot this if I don't have access to an environment that fails.

Joe, do you have any more information on your setup?"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-27 01:45:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-27 06:32:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I still can't reproduce the problem reported, but I've pushed up an updated branch to my github which is much more defensive. It also has some bug fixes which may or may not fix the root cause seen.

If anyone can reproduce the problem with the Gerrit branch, can you give this github branch a try?

https://github.com/jerdfelt/nova/tree/multi-process-api"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-06-27 06:57:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

FWIW... I had pulled the branch before the last patch set and it works fine for me as well.  I watched top during it... and i saw the main process use ~250M of ram for most of it... and then jumped to around 500M towards the end... but didn't go higher.   No signs of multiple processes or anything going out of control."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-06-27 06:59:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Er.. sorry, I guess I tested this latest patch set.  Forgot that the defensive patch had gone to github.  Anyway... point is, I can't reproduce the issue..so looks like I'll be no help."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-27 13:35:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Chris, I agree with you about the semantics of SIGHUP/SIGTERM. I tried to follow the behavior of the previous patch, but it's a bit non-standard.

The version up on github drops handling SIGHUP and treats SIGTERM/SIGINT like a graceful shutdown. If the admin doesn't want that, they can kill the process again (since the handlers are reset after the first signal), or they can use SIGKILL."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-06-27 15:04:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: No score

Oh awesome, thanks..  That's much better."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-06-27 15:53:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Pulling this locally onto xUbuntu 12.04 to see if I can reproduce anything...'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-06-27 16:27:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Unfortunately, doing ./run_tests.sh -V locally puts my machine into a death spiral. Dozens of nosetests processes spawn and the only way I was able to take control was to killall nosetests. By the time I got there, the processes were chewing up nearly half a gig of RAM :("}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-06-27 16:28:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

testing the GH defensive branch now.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-06-27 17:42:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Johannes, unfortunately, I pulled your GH branch and ran the test suite. It hung on the first test (CloudTestCase.test_allocate_address) and I had to terminate the process. Cleared and reinstalled my venv just to be sure and had the same results :('}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-06-27 17:51:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Johannes,  I am running the tests on a Ubuntu 12.04 Box.    I am currently retrying with your GH branch.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-27 17:53:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Jay, make sure none of the lock files are hanging around. I ran into a similar problem and the nova-iptables.lock was still there and the test suite doesn't clean them up first."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-27 18:13:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I've been able to reproduce the problems Joe, Jay and Jenkins have seen on my Ubuntu 11.10 system.

It appears to be a combination of a race condition between the parent dying and the child reading on a closed pipe, that triggers a bug in eventlet, which then triggers a bug in this older version of the patch.

I've filed a bug for eventlet:

https://bitbucket.org/which_linden/eventlet/issue/123/hubs-epollspy-uses-get_errno-but-does-not

and I've submitted a pull request for the fix to eventlet:

https://bitbucket.org/which_linden/eventlet/pull-request/16/import-errno-and-get_errno-so-exception

My defensive branch solves the bug that eventlet exposed, but the test hangs still (but at least it doesn't spawn off processes like before). I'm still working on troubleshooting that.

With the eventlet patch applied, then the tests pass for me even with the older code."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-06-27 18:21:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Johannes,

Glad to see you found the problem.

When running your GH branch (via ./run_tests.sh -f ) this is what I get:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/18909/'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-27 18:28:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Joe, that is the same behavior I get with my GH branch right now (and without the eventlet patch applied).

The tracebacks show the eventlet bug (get_errno and errno aren't being imported). The fact it hangs and doesn't properly fail the tests is still a bug I'm tracking down.

FWIW, the eventlet patch got merged into their trunk already. (Very quick!)"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-27 19:40:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-27 19:46:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Ok, we should be all good now. This version works even with the buggy eventlet.

The problem was caused by sharing of the epoll fd across children. That would cause an EEXIST error to occur which eventlet is supposed to ignore (specifically for this case).

The code ran just fine, but to avoid triggering the eventlet bug as well as make sure there isn't unexpected behavior in the future, I changed the patch to reopen the hub and use a new epoll fd.

This version also has a few other minor bug fixes and cleanups relative to the previous version."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-27 19:57:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

This is based on Huang Zhiteng's patch.

is primarily intended to be used with the API service as a way to provide

is primarily intended to be used with the API service as a way to provide
more concurrency than eventlet can sometimes provide.

A SIGTERM signal will cause the parent process to send a SIGTERM to the

commit_message:
Add multi-process support for API services

Implements blueprint multi-process-api-service

This is based on Huang Zhiteng's patch.

This patch adds support for running services as multiple processes. This
is primarily intended to be used with the API service as a way to provide
more concurrency than eventlet can sometimes provide.

A SIGTERM or SIGINT signal will cause the parent process to gracefully
terminate the child processes, allowing them to finish processing the
requests currently being processed. The parent will wait for the
children to finish before exiting.

Change-Id: Ie6d6802626eb42d5e64c4167be363fbf6cea2a1b

 2.note,nova-network use ec2-instance-id in iptables rule,the name of a  rule can't use the long name(with more than 36 characters),may need a mapping here."}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-06-20 05:52:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(4 inline comments)

I disagree with renaming the uuid column to "id" in instances. I think its clearer to developers if the uuid column is just left with that name and made the primary key column if you want to drop the "id" column.

I'm also not really clear on what we gain here by moving the id to uuid mapping out of the instances table. I agree that its a bit dated that the id is the primary key here, but I don't think its actively harmful.

Can you please explain?'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-06-20 05:57:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

rather than creating the mapping at instance create time, you should create the mapping on demand by creating a method in ec2utils similar to:

166 def get_int_id_from_volume_uuid(context, volume_uuid):
167     if volume_uuid is None:
168         return
169     try:
170         return db.get_ec2_volume_id_by_uuid(context, volume_uuid)
171     except exception.NotFound:
172         return db.ec2_volume_create(context, volume_uuid)['id']

and a method like:

147 def id_to_ec2_vol_id(volume_id):
148     """Get or create an ec2 volume ID (vol-[base 16 number]) from uuid."""
149     if utils.is_uuid_like(volume_id):
150         ctxt = context.get_admin_context()
151         int_id = get_int_id_from_volume_uuid(ctxt, volume_id)
152         return id_to_ec2_id(int_id, 'vol-%08x')
153     else:
154         return id_to_ec2_id(volume_id, 'vol-%08x')


and use that method whenever an ec2 id is needed.

so you need get_int_id_from_instance_id and id_to_ec2_inst_id and then replace all calls to id_to_ec2_id with the new method.

You also need a migration that copies all existing ids into the new table so instance ids don't change.'}, {'account_id': 1313, 'date': '2012-06-20 11:15:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-20 12:24:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

currently uses the id column in the instances table. This patch
creates a new mapping table for ec2-ids. This decouples the ec2
layer from needing direct access to the instances table so that
it can eventually be pulled out if necessary. It also matches the
way that the ec2 layer maps image, volume, and snaphsot ids.

commit_message:
Implement blueprint ec2-id-compatibilty.

Instance ids are used by the ec2 layer to create ec2-ids. This
currently uses the id column in the instances table. This patch
creates a new mapping table for ec2-ids. This decouples the ec2
layer from needing direct access to the instances table so that
it can eventually be pulled out if necessary. It also matches the
way that the ec2 layer maps image, volume, and snaphsot ids.
Finally, it allows us to eventually remove the id column from
the instances table and only have one canonical id (uuid) to
refer to instances.

Change-Id: I02ad9fad37e6a04675543398f686351634bc1bb9

commit_message:
Allow CONF.notifier_strategy to be a full path

Rather than limit the notifier_strategy to a list of internal
drivers, we should also allow a user to supply a full path
to a custom driver. This is going to help us functionally test
our notification system without having to ship a fake driver.

Fixes bug 1018638

Change-Id: Ib1cae7b979dabfaa6b8b5aa59719aad2ac12d169

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-14 12:19:08.000000000', 'message': "Allow specification of the libvirt guest CPU model per host

Currently Nova does not configure any CPU model for libvirt
guests. This is sub-optimal because the default KVM CPU
model has changed a number of times, and more importantly
VMs are not able to take advantage of many performance
features in newer CPUs. To get a consistent CPU model exposed
to the guest and maximize performance of VMs in the cloud,
explicit specification of CPU models per host is desirable.

This change adds a new Nova config flag:

  libvirt_cpu_mode = host-model|host-passthrough|custom

Where

  * host-model == configure a model that matches the features
                  available in the host CPU

  * host-passthrough == passthrough the host CPU precisely
                        with no change at all

  * custom == configure a specific named CPU model

If the 'custom' mode is used, then the additional flag
is avialable to choose the model:

  libvirt_cpu_model = <one of the names from /usr/share/libvirt/cpu_model.xml>

eg

  libvirt_cpu_model = core2duo

If specifying a custom CPU model, it is wise to choose one that is
capable of running on all the various different Nova hosts in the
cloud. That said, libvirt will enforce compatibility at time of
starting or migrating guests & refuse the operation if required.

If using either the host-model or host-passthrough modes, and use
of live migration is desired, admins should ensure that all hosts
have a homogeneous CPU model. If hosts have a hetergeneous CPU
models, then a custom named CPU model is a better choice

Fixes: bug #1003373
Implements: blueprint libvirt-xml-cpu-model
Change-Id: I90ce78d7e29bd0d563e3bc547b7cc5d64dd9496e
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Allow specification of the libvirt guest CPU model per host

Currently Nova does not configure any CPU model for libvirt
guests. This is sub-optimal because the default KVM CPU
model has changed a number of times, and more importantly
VMs are not able to take advantage of many performance
features in newer CPUs. To get a consistent CPU model exposed
to the guest and maximize performance of VMs in the cloud,
explicit specification of CPU models per host is desirable.

This change adds a new Nova config flag:

  libvirt_cpu_mode = host-model|host-passthrough|custom

Where

  * host-model == configure a model that matches the features
                  available in the host CPU

  * host-passthrough == passthrough the host CPU precisely
                        with no change at all

  * custom == configure a specific named CPU model

If the 'custom' mode is used, then the additional flag
is available to choose the model:

  libvirt_cpu_model = <one of the names from /usr/share/libvirt/cpu_model.xml>

eg

  libvirt_cpu_model = core2duo

If specifying a custom CPU model, it is wise to choose one that is
capable of running on all the various different Nova hosts in the
cloud. That said, libvirt will enforce compatibility at time of
starting or migrating guests & refuse the operation if required.

If using either the host-model or host-passthrough modes, and use
of live migration is desired, admins should ensure that all hosts
have a homogeneous CPU model. If hosts have a hetergeneous CPU
models, then a custom named CPU model is a better choice

This configuration only works for libvirt >= 0.9.10, due to the
use of the 'mode' attribute on the <cpu> element for configuring
host models.

Fixes: bug #1003373
Implements: blueprint libvirt-xml-cpu-model
Change-Id: I90ce78d7e29bd0d563e3bc547b7cc5d64dd9496e
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Adds default fall-through to the multi scheduler.
Fixes bug 1009681

This offers a default scheduler driver that will be used by the
multischeduler for requests that are not destined for the
compute or volume topic. This is useful for openstack extensions
that want to use the nova-scheduler to schedule requests to
compute nodes but provide their own manager and topic.

Change-Id: I753e87fc8979fd0b62529974f00cf11fa55b3d63

The server MUST NOT contain an id, tentant_id, user_id, hostId, progress, updated or created. The server also not contain an embeded image an flavor, addresses, or an asynch fault. Please change this block of text to the following (or similar to the following): When creating a server, the server MUST NOT contain the id, tenant_id, user_id, hostId, progress, updated, or created attributes. The server also cannot contain an embedded image, a flavor, addresses, or an asynchronous fault."}, {'account_id': 143, 'date': '2012-06-28 18:25:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned Looks like max_count and min_count are extensions -- backing out.'}]

commit_message:
Add hypervisor information extension.

Adds a new extension to get information about hypervisors (as opposed
to compute hosts), including a list of hypervisors matching a regular
expression (database regular expression, i.e., %'s) and a list of
hypervisors with the list of instances living on those hypervisors.

Change-Id: I2e44e82e123e5e727b49622fe5e966131658f9f6

commit_message:
Switch libvirt get_cpu_info method over to use config APIs

The get_cpu_info method in the libvirt driver currently uses
XPath queries to extract information from the capabilities
XML document. Switch this over to use the new config class
LibvirtConfigCaps. Also provide a test case to validate
the data being returned

Fixes: bug #1003373
Implements: blueprint libvirt-xml-cpu-model
Change-Id: I4946a16d27f712ae2adf8441ce78e6c0bb0bb657
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

Hi Micheal,

I'm seeing some errors when running this branch:

 column "instance_uuid" of relation "instance_info_caches" does not exist.

See line 356 of this paste for more information:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/18542/'}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-06-15 18:00:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

uuid is an id. We've gone to great lengths from the network side of things to refer to instances only by their uuids because network services live above or outside of compute services. As a result we just refer to the id as instance_id as there is no point in having both. I realize this table is inside nova, but the cache holds only network data."}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-06-15 18:16:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

vish and i discussed. It doesn't really affect much of anything except readability. I do wish we just used instance_id everywhere, and maybe eventually we will. For now eh, I'm fine either way."}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-06-15 23:27:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Vish asked me to make this change. I'm happy enough to drop it if its going to cause people problems, but I do like the idea of nova being internally consistent.

I assume you're using the nova db api to access these tables, right? So this change should be transparent to the networking code?"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-06-18 21:13:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

See how the failure is in a packaged version of nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py ? Yeah, that's not going to work because that code was updated as part of this change.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-06-28 02:02:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Michael,

Actually SmokeStack builds custom packages for each change set that it tests. What it does is checkout your patch set and then build a fresh set of RPMs from it. So it would make sense that the stack trace contains references to /usr/lib/python2.7/....

SmokeStack is all about packages, config management, etc... trying to make the deployment a bit more realistic than a source install.

I'll try to have a closer look at this tomorrow morning to see if I can help out. One thing to keep in mind is I'm running PostgreSQL as a default right now. If it helps I'm also able to try MySQL (its button click so I'm happy to try it if it helps).

Dan"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-06-28 02:25:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
Rename the instance_id column in instance_info_caches.

The name was confusing, because it was a uuid in a column named
instance_id.

Change-Id: I0df0fe84b4891da9529639cf8c07c3e4d86a9958

commit_message:
Add full test environment.

Add a tox environment that will install all of the optional
packages and which will run with system site packages enabled
so that we pick up those tests as well. This should allow us
to run expansive tests on jenkins that aren't normally required
locally, but which are possible.

Change-Id: Iabd61874061e24950d4d2082a2fba158b4601624

commit_message:
Add libvirt config classes for handling capabilities XML doc

Libvirt exposes the host/hypervisor features using an XML
schema known as "capabilities". Currently the libvirt driver
code just parses this in an adhoc manner using xpath queries.

This change provides a handful of classes LibvirtConfigCaps,
LibvirtConfigCapsHost and LibvirtConfigCapsGuest for maintaining
an object based representation of the capabilities. The
LibvirtConfigCapsHost class also uses the existing LibvirtConfigCPU
class

Fixes: bug #1003373
Implements: blueprint libvirt-xml-cpu-model
Change-Id: Ie962c6378b0da09eddc75983d4824a226ed1c25e
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-18 11:44:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

Nice work Dan, some minor comments inline

Jenkins failures seem to be down to pypi errors"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-06-18 12:21:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (3 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-18 13:09:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I have a tendency to delete unused code when I see it in the codebase, so please save me the trouble of doing that after you commit :)

Seriously, this isn't a general purpose python binding for libvirt XML config (although such a thing would be useful), so it should only have what Nova needs.

If your rationale made sense, we'd need to later accept patches to add (a) support for new additions to the XML schema that Nova isn't using and (b) support for XML configuration that some proprietary extension is allegedly using. I don't think we want to go down that road."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-06-18 13:20:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I can see the value in deleting dead code in general, since most dead code is just plain broken, or unlikely to ever be useful again.

In the case of the libvirt config class modules though, I still disagree with this policy you suggest, because I think it is a disservice to downstream developers/users of OpenStack to remove stuff that is not broken (it has unit test coverage), and has real potential usage (for extending the capabilities of libvirt driver).'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-18 13:37:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

You wouldn't add unused/unusable code (tested or not) to libvirt. There's no difference here.

Honestly, I think this could be a nice, standalone, general purpose library - if you want to make it cover all of the libvirt schema, split it out of Nova."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-06-18 16:09:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> You wouldn't add unused/unusable code (tested or not) to libvirt. There's no difference here.

The key question here, I think, is what our intentions are towards downstream users / developers. If we are aiming to facilitate downsteam users/developers extending & customizing the libvirt connection driver, then I think this code does have a valid usage scenario, even though usage is not part of the Nova core codebase itself. If we intend to say downstream users are completely on their own wrt extending/customizing the libvirt driver at a code level, then we can leave out the unused config classes.

My code is based on the assumption that we want to facilitate downstream derivative work on the Nova code, not merely deployment.


> Honestly, I think this could be a nice, standalone, general purpose library - if you want to make it cover all of the libvirt schema, split it out of Nova.

From a libvirt community POV we're pushing libvirt-gconfig as our standalone library API for managing XML documents. Unfortunately we can't use that in Nova at this point in time, because it would effectively lock out deployment from any distro pre-dating Fedora 16 vintage, due to the requirement for GObject Introspection (that stablized at approx the GTK3 release date). I don't want to encourage other apps to use this python config code in Nova, and hope that with time (1-2 years time?), we'll be able to remove it from Nova in favour of libvirt-gconfig."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-18 16:31:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> If we are aiming to facilitate downsteam users/developers extending & customizing the libvirt connection driver

We're facilitating it by releasing the code under a license which makes it possible, but ...

We can't get into a situation where we're adding code "because a 3rd party might use it" - that put's an awful lot of random stuff in scope and we have no way of knowing whether people are using it

Here's an example of other "unused code" in Nova:

  https://lists.launchpad.net/openstack/msg12200.html

but even that (which I don't think should have happened without some way of using it) is far more sensible since it's easily usable through one of our supported extension points - i.e. by adding a middleware which adds quota_class to the request context.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-06-19 14:47:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-06-19 14:48:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

None of the parts previously noted as 'unused' have been removed in v2, since the need to support old libvirt < 0.9.10 means they are in fact now used."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-19 15:59:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Cool, thanks Dan

Some of the stuff here is just used by the fallback implementation of host-model and I've some questions on that, so +0 for now"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-19 16:33:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Refactor libvirt config classes for representing CPU models/features

The previously added (but not used) LibvirtConfigCPUTest class
was too inflexible. It did not distinguish between parts of the
XML schema which applied to both capabilities & domain XML,
vs those which only applied to the domain XML. By representing
features as a plain string it did not allow for setting attributes
on feature flags like policy.  This change replaces the single
LibvirtConfigCPUTest class with 4 new classes:

 - LibvirtConfigCPUFeature - base class for defining CPU features
 - LibvirtConfigCPU - base class for defining CPU models
 - LibvirtConfigGuestCPUFeature - extension for setting the guest
   specific feature policy
 - LibvirtConfigGuestCPU - extension for setting the guest specific
   match policy, and allowing use of host CPU model passthrough

Fixes: bug #1003373
Implements: blueprint libvirt-xml-cpu-model
Change-Id: I0aa0ddfb86cf8b89b2e4dcc95e21bdca304bd6b3
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Use rpc from openstack-common.

Final patch for blueprint common-rpc.

This patch removes nova.rpc in favor of the copy in openstack-common.

[{'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-06-25 22:56:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

And I don't see a blueprint in the commit message."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-06-25 23:07:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

That said, I have some immediate comments on the actual implementation inline."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-25 23:07:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Unless I misunderstand what you're confused about?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-25 23:14:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-25 23:28:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Johannes:

I'm more interested in moving the virt drivers closer together than further apart. Yes, they are fundamentally different in certain aspects, I'd prefer not to make that problem worse. I will admit that I'm not the best judge of what is doable versus what's not with respect to xen and libvirt, so I will have to depend on your expertise for that. And while I agree this is a cool feature, I want all deployers of OpenStack to be able to use it. It's not adding enough value if it's only useful for the minority of deployments. Is that not a goal we share?"}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-06-25 23:29:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Brian

> I'm confused why this is specific to xen. Why can't we implement this in a common way? 

The short answer is, it mirrors the current design we have in XenServer land of using dom0 to fetch images and the domU compute manager to build instances.

Instead of having just a `glance` plugin, we now have a `glance` and `bittorrent` plugin.

> This is only going to be useful to a very specific group of people if not. 

I think that's fine for a first cut. If we determine that the performance gain is worth it (this is still experimental so we really haven't gathered any concrete metrics yet), then we can look for ways to port this to other virt-layer drivers.

But, I don't think that effort will be trivial given how differently the drivers treat images, hence wanting to leave it for down the road.

> And I don't see a blueprint in the commit message.

This is a work-in-progress intended to gather some early-stage feedback. Will have BP before it goes up as a real review."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-25 23:35:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

>> I'm confused why this is specific to xen. Why can't we implement this in a common way?
>The short answer is, it mirrors the current design we have in XenServer land of using dom0 to fetch images and the domU compute manager to build instances.
>Instead of having just a `glance` plugin, we now have a `glance` and `bittorrent` plugin.

Why not have a local bittorrent module that knows how to use bittorrent to download an arbitrary file? The bittorrent plugin code really has nothing to do with xen, or even images, right?

>> This is only going to be useful to a very specific group of people if not.
> I think that's fine for a first cut. If we determine that the performance gain is worth it (this is still experimental so we really haven't gathered any concrete metrics yet), then we can look for ways to port this to other virt-layer drivers.
>But, I don't think that effort will be trivial given how differently the drivers treat images, hence wanting to leave it for down the road.

My gut reaction when something is left to be cleaned up later is that it isn't ever actually going to get done. I fear that we are going to leave a substantial bit of work that you could minimize with some extra effort up front.

>> And I don't see a blueprint in the commit message.
> This is a work-in-progress intended to gather some early-stage feedback. Will have BP before it goes up as a real review.

Loud and clear."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-06-25 23:50:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Why not have a local bittorrent module that knows how to use bittorrent to download an arbitrary file? The bittorrent plugin code really has nothing to do with xen, or even images, right?

Sort-of. Ideally, we should be completely image agnostic, but in the XenServer case, for now, we're having to download the image into a special staging area we set aside within the storage repository. This code lives in dom0 which is why code that exists between the creation and tear down of the staging area, for convenience, also tends to be in dom0.

We could do some refactoring (potentially) to "fix" this, but that would be more general refactoring that I think would be beyond the scope of this patch.

I think philosophically we may just disagree here: I'd vote that we go ahead and add this in a minimally invasive way to XenServer and see how it goes. If it proves successful, then I think there will be plenty of impetus for us to move forward with a more unified solution. But my guess is that final design won't look like what we currently have, but something completely different that develop over the course of a few iterations.

> My gut reaction when something is left to be cleaned up later is that it isn't ever actually going to get done. I fear that we are going to leave a substantial bit of work that you could minimize with some extra effort up front.


If it works, then I think the libvirt-world will be jealous enough of the fast build times on the XenServer side to port it over.

If it doesn't work, then Johannes or I will be the first the yank this code out so we can keep the XenServer code at a reasonable side.

Either way, I think it will reach a happy-equilibrium.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-26 00:46:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I can't say I'm a big fan of doing so much work in Xen dom0. It has an old userspace and installing executables on there is a bad idea.

In general I think we should strive for making the drivers closer and this shouldn't be an exception.

But making bittorrent integration generic for all drivers will be difficult. The dom0 is going to be a thorn in our side.

A naive implementation of putting the bittorrent functionality on the compute node will mean you're adding extra copies of images between domU and dom0."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-06-26 01:55:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thinking out loud here, here's my understanding of why functionality has migrated into dom0, for better or worse:

1. WE WANT TO WORK WITH VHDs

By virtue of being sparse (only containing used blocks), VHDs ensure we only copy the data we need to, keeping builds and snapshots relatively fast.

This is why we standardized on using a tarball of VHDs as our preferred image format.

2. XENAPI DOESN"T LET US WORK DIRECTLY WITH VHDS

The XenAPI is designed such that VHD is only one of many possible disk formats, so the abstractions provided via virtual-block-devices and storage-repositories, do not expose VHDs directly.

To gain access to the VHDs, we can (among other options), mount the SR over NFS, or manipulate it using a dom0 plugin.

At the initial Openstack Summit (Austin), after discussing it with some of the Citrix folks, the dom0 plugin was picked as the least-worst option.

3. OPTIMIZATIONS LEAD TO OTHER CODE MIGRATING INTO DOM0

Once we start having to move around VHDs using a dom0 plugin, we soon want to optimize so that we're not unnecessarily copying files. 

As an example, rather than download the tarball (hitting disk), untaring it (hitting disk again), and moving those file into the storage repository, we'd rather set up pipeline where the data is downloaded, untarred, and then renamed into the storage repository, hitting disk once.

These kind of optimizations led to the downloading and uploading code moving into dom0 as well.

--

In general, I agree with the sentiment that the less code in dom0 the better, but I'm unsure how we can (in the short term) have both optimized *and* virt-independent code.

At some risk of incurring (hopefully temporary) technical debt, I'd rather we let a thousand flowers bloom: see what works on each side of the virt-layer divide, strive to unify it over time, and where it doesn't work, be vicious in removing it.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-06-26 15:11:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

FWIW (and not commenting on the specific implementation here...) the libvirt ImageCache is specific to libvirt deployments, no? And we don't seem to have a problem with that..."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-26 15:31:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Jay:

That is very true, but that already exists. The first step is to stop widening the gap.

From here on out, consider me not a part of this review :)'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-06-26 21:40:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-26 22:04:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Add ability to download images via BitTorrent.

This patch adds a new dom0 plugin which supports downloading images via
BitTorrent. Torrent metadata files are assumed to be served from a
webserver which is specified by the `torrent_base_url` config.

Implements BP xenserver-bittorrent-images

Change-Id: I8a9701692c49bec752310edac68092962c0430e2

subject: Remove hard coded man page paths.
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-22 17:08:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-merge/326/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-pep8/102/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-python26/211/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-python27/209/testReport : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-06-27 23:26:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I can maybe understand the lack of /usr/share/doc but if /etc/init.d scripts are missing won't that cause problems with a lot of deployment scripts out there?"}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-06-28 06:54:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I am not sure I like having the path references removed. I understand those path are biased to Ubuntu distribution and that's not ideal for the other distributions.

How's that work for other OSS projects ? From my experience usually packagers would do a large sed replacement in the %install section of the rpm specfile to get the right path in the package, right?

I know that on C based OSS projects we usually have manpages finishing by a .in suffix and have a @PATH@ macros that m4 proceed with the right prefix when doing make install allowing packager to easily override it. I am not sure if that's something easy to replicate with a python's distutils project."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-06-28 12:40:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Chmouel:

I suppose I thought Swift (like other OpenStack projects) should be distro agnostic... and not choose on distro over another in terms of hard coding things in the source code.

I'm not sure I see a huge value add for keeping these in the codebase... but I suppose if we want to go that route and look into using variables for these locations we can.

My preference would still be to remove these entirely."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-06-28 13:09:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Well, man pages != source code.

And it's overdramatic to declare something as preferring one distribution of Linux because it references /etc/init.d and /usr/share/doc. I don't mind disagreement, but let's not get silly.

Besides, if we're going the route of "you can't mention anything that might resemble referencing a particular distribution" there are a lot more specific references in the documentation you could have gone after (search for Ubuntu or Fedora in doc).

But aside from that, can you mention what specific differences you've found? What distro? Where do they put what we're putting under /etc/init.d and /usr/share/doc?'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-06-28 13:28:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

gholt:

Agree that man pages are source code. I'm not trying to be overdramatic... but I just don't see the value add in keeping this in.

On F17:

Docs go in.... 

/usr/share/doc/openstack-swift-1234 (where 1234 is the version of the swift package installed)

Note the package name difference w/ openstack-swift... instead of just swift.

Also F17 uses systemd which puts its files in the 

/usr/lib/systemd/system/

If the preference is that we leave these in I suppose I can put in conditionals for these:

On Fedora:
....

On Ubuntu:
....

Would that work instead? I really feel like this may ultimately lead to a distro explosion however. So if we want to keep it in the docs I think using some sort of parameters instead might be preferable."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-06-28 13:43:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Thanks Dan,

Yeah with those differences I'd go with removing these references from the man pages as well. There are references to the website where folks can (hopefully) get all the information they need if they don't happen to know where their system installs init scripts and docs."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-28 15:29:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Starting gate jobs.'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-06-28 15:29:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-28 10:37:10.000000000', 'message': "Fix regression in test_connection_to_primitive libvirt testcase

Commit aa9a592abcbfabad4d2a3f8bb49d1b28d7724262, which renamed
the libvirt module from 'connection' -> 'driver', accidentally
introduced a flaw in the test_connection_to_primitive libvirt
testcase.

The original code in that test case was

   connection = nova.virt.libvirt.connection.LibvirtDriver('')
   jsonutils.to_primitive(connection._conn, convert_instances=True)

Notice how the second line is using the '_conn' attribute on
the LibvirtDriver *object instance*

Now the new code is

   connection = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver('')
   jsonutils.to_primitive(libvirt_driver._conn, convert_instances=True)

Notice how the second line is using the '_conn' attribute on
the LibvirtDriver *class*. Predictably this causes the testcase
to fail due to the '_conn' attribute not existing.

Change-Id: Ie35718ea0c50648938effc53d67a110f280644d6
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Fix regression in test_connection_to_primitive libvirt testcase

Commit aa9a592abcbfabad4d2a3f8bb49d1b28d7724262, which renamed
the libvirt module from 'connection' -> 'driver', accidentally
introduced a flaw in the test_connection_to_primitive libvirt
testcase.

The original code in that test case was

   connection = nova.virt.libvirt.connection.LibvirtDriver('')
   jsonutils.to_primitive(connection._conn, convert_instances=True)

Notice how the second line is using the '_conn' attribute on
the LibvirtDriver *object instance*

Now the new code is

   connection = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver('')
   jsonutils.to_primitive(libvirt_driver._conn, convert_instances=True)

Notice how the second line is using the '_conn' attribute on
the LibvirtDriver *class*. Predictably this causes the testcase
to fail due to the '_conn' attribute not existing.

Change-Id: Ie35718ea0c50648938effc53d67a110f280644d6
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Rename GlanceImageService.get to download

In preparation for integration with the new Glance client, this
drops the return of image metadata from GlanceImageService.get
in addition to renaming it to 'download'.

Change-Id: I75ca3a0a909335e74cd521da6f894c163e773e94

commit_message:
Migrate existing routes from flat_interface

Right now, any routes that exist on flat_interface (other than the default
route) get lost when we set up the bridge. This patch migrates them over
to avoid losing that connectivity. It does so by using 'ip route' instead
of 'route', which is much easier to script and is consistent with other
use of iproute2 tools in linux_net.py.

Bug 962822

Change-Id: I7d9e8e05169f2f87e8481595397c02fd3a3612f4

'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-06-15 11:14:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Pretty cool I have tested it and it works pretty well. A few minor questions :

what's the difference between path_qs and path, do we need the two of them ? is there path with query string in keystone ?

This is by default stored in memory wouldn't be growing pretty large the keystone process if there is a /lot/ of different keystone requests? 

And your commit messages says :

Reset statistics report:
  GET http://keystone:35357/v2.0/OS-STATS/stats

should probably be  a DELETE"}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-06-15 20:35:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-06-15 20:44:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

path_qs vs path: Yes, path_qs includes query strings whereas path is simply the resource. So, path_qs will include calls to GET /tokens/{token_id}?belongsTo={tenant_id}, tenant list paging, etc. I found myself looking at 'path' first at a high level, and then looking into 'path_qs' for additional detail. A client could certainly parse path_qs and generate their own copy of path, however, so if we want to exclude it for memory/bandwidth usage, I'd be fine with that.

As for in-memory usage, if you think that would be an issue, I'd be happy to either exclude it from the sample pipeline, or rename the filters to something like debug_stats_monitoring debug_stats_reporting to discourage use in production. Thoughts?

Thanks for the catch on my commit message! (copypasta fail!)"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-15 20:45:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-keystone-merge/1272/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-keystone-pep8/1339/ : UNSTABLE
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-keystone-python26/371/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-keystone-python27/368/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/5361/ : SUCCESS
"}, {'account_id': 1032, 'date': '2012-06-18 15:37:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I am against renaming this middleware to discourage usage in production environmnets. This is exactly the kind of information that administrators need in operating a production environment. 

If memory usage is a concern, I would like to see an alternative storage implementation for the data.. maybe a memcached or file based alternative.'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-06-19 14:17:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I agreed with Justin's comment this probably going to be something people want to use in production. 

I don't think it would cause too much problems as this would really need a lot of requests to get a OOM and before then the service would be probably already restarted (or scaled horizontally to other keystone servers).

I think if people want to rely on this in production they would need be able to have it stored in another backend than memory. IMO it would be nice to have it integrated with a system like statsd and the way done in swift https://github.com/pandemicsyn/swift-informant which would avoid us to take care of logging to file/flushing logs/ rotation etc... 

anyway those are just suggestions as it stands this review is a solid +1 for me."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-06-19 19:16:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-06-19 19:16:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
Basic request stats monitoring & reporting

Attributes are tracked seperately per interface (public API vs admin API):
- Request method (GETs, POSTs, etc)
- Requested resources
- Number of requests per remote address
- Response status codes

Retrieve statistics report:
  GET http://keystone:35357/v2.0/OS-STATS/stats
  e.g. http://paste.openstack.org/raw/18528/

Reset statistics report:
  DELETE http://keystone:35357/v2.0/OS-STATS/stats

Change-Id: Id21af755e5e25b8275dd55b7415bf4c421304807

commit_message:
fix syntax error in the if test

switch to using -f rather than -a. This has been overlooked
in a review recently merged. Without this fix, devstack on
XenServer is broken.

Change-Id: I1882cc70528772287241848adea3a520738d4144

commit_message:
refactor libvirt from connection -> driver

part of bp:virt-driver-cleanup

part d) of the blueprint is to get rid of the connection terminology
and use driver instead. This does this for the libvirt driver and
associated tests.

Also add LibvirtDriver import to __init__ so that
nova.virt.libvirt.LibvirtDriver can be used as the compute_driver
string

Change-Id: I13c701c390784fa1f7809705741abb46e40973be

commit_message:
Use buffered gzip stream with python 2.7.

- Fixes bug 898169.
- It's possible to make GzipFile inherits io.BufferedIOBase in python
  2.6, but IMO it's better let people to use 2.7 if they really need
  this feature.

Change-Id: I4c6e4858e3f616af892e7f4fa6daae0f6ee31723

(1 inline comment)

Thank you for fixing the first line of the commit message. However, it would be nice to have "Fixes bug NNNNN" in the commit message somewhere.

The commit message here refers to the ring builder running out of RAM, but the bug in question talks about a bitshift raising ValueError. I can certainly see the ValueError happening, but I don't understand how that would cause the ring builder to consume memory without bound. Could you clarify?

Also, I'd like a unit test for this behavior. It doesn't have to be too fancy; a simple assertRaises() will be sufficient.'}, {'account_id': 3004, 'date': '2012-06-19 06:00:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-19 06:04:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-13 11:09:12.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes bug 924577

Raised a value error if the
part_power is greater than 32
as part_power greater than 32 making the
part_shift to be negative.

Change-Id: I61bd36f2bc0ac66af212203cfa736d4652a89156
'}, {'created': '2012-06-13 12:48:37.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes problem of partition power >32

Raised a value error if the
part_power is greater than 32.
If part_power is greater than 32
then part_shift will be negative
in the ring data class and thus
swif-ring-builder runs out of RAM
when trying to rebalance a ring.

Change-Id: I61bd36f2bc0ac66af212203cfa736d4652a89156
'}, {'created': '2012-06-19 06:00:52.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes problem of partition power >32

Retested the bug,actually when we
give part_power greater than 32
(suppose 33) it was taking
long time to rebalance (almost could
be considered as indefinite loop).
According to bug raiser ,I have
checked up the part_power in ring
builder init method and raised a value
error if part_power greater than 32

Fixes bug 924577

Change-Id: I61bd36f2bc0ac66af212203cfa736d4652a89156
'}]
commit_message:
Fixes problem of partition power >32

Retested the bug,actually when we
give part_power greater than 32
(suppose 33) it was taking
long time to rebalance (almost could
be considered as indefinite loop).
According to bug raiser ,I have
checked up the part_power in ring
builder init method and raised a value
error if part_power greater than 32

Fixes bug 924577

Change-Id: I61bd36f2bc0ac66af212203cfa736d4652a89156

All the other settings are at the top where you can easily see them.

commit_message:
Make the extra floating ip pool optional in tests

If $TEST_FLOATING_POOL is set to "skip", the tests involving this extra
pool of floating ip's will be skipped.

Change-Id: I232c0ac53074655e7abc8e368f40045623addd09

commit_message:
Remove GlanceImageService.index in favor of detail

Since there is no difference in index vs detail in the v2 API,
let's drop that as a requirement in the GlanceImageService.

Related to bp integrate-python-glanceclient

Change-Id: If98cf68e7e18fa78a2f9c09526ca9e80d2e27c1b

commit_message:
Remove image service show_by_name method

This method isn't worth keeping around. It's used in one place and
consists of a try/except block. We also shouldn't encourage clients
of GlanceImageService to depend on finding a single unique image
by a non-unique attribute.

Change-Id: I02347adef7bc7ac70407226ea150000e55a798bc

commit_message:
Cleanup of image service code

* Remove image_service flag
* Move nova.image.fake to nova.tests.image.fake
* Move nova.image.get_default_image_service to
  nova.image.glance.get_default_image_service
* Move nova.image.get_image_service to
  nova.image.glance.get_remote_image_service
* Related to bp integrate-python-glanceclient

Change-Id: Iea6db7898328a9060fb88586e042efbc0a4351fc

added min_count and max_count attributes to create server

patch: updated min_count and max_count attributes to make them optional

patch: updated max_count to indicate quota limits are tested against the request

commit_message:
Allow removing services explicitly.

- When adding a - (hyphen) at the begining of a service in
  ENABLED_SERVICES the service will be removed explicitly.

Change-Id: I69ce082d13b79aa88426e8012a941c4ae99741f6

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-26 19:01:08.000000000', 'message': "Split reading of versioninfo out into a method

Make the read_versioninfo to match write_versioninfo.

Additionally, there is an edge case where if the code is installed from a
github zipball, versioning info is missing. Now that we're using this,
there should be virtual no instances where a zipball will be easier or
less cost than an sdist created tarball, all of which should be public and
accessible, but during the transition, we need to account for the codepath.

Change-Id: Icd3fe97c6341bb04da27adc55a85f1ab6b525c46
"}, {'created': '2012-06-26 19:03:52.000000000', 'message': "Split reading of versioninfo out into a method

Additionally, there is an edge case where if the code is installed from a
github zipball, versioning info is missing. Now that we're using this,
there should be virtual no instances where a zipball will be easier or
less cost than an sdist created tarball, all of which should be public and
accessible, but during the transition, we need to account for the codepath.

Change-Id: Icd3fe97c6341bb04da27adc55a85f1ab6b525c46
"}, {'created': '2012-06-26 19:05:51.000000000', 'message': "Split reading of versioninfo out into a method

Make the read_versioninfo to match write_versioninfo.

Additionally, there is an edge case where if the code is installed from a
github zipball, versioning info is missing. Now that we're using this,
there should be virtual no instances where a zipball will be easier or
less cost than an sdist created tarball, all of which should be public and
accessible, but during the transition, we need to account for the codepath.

Change-Id: Icd3fe97c6341bb04da27adc55a85f1ab6b525c46

commit_message:
Split reading of versioninfo out into a method

Make the read_versioninfo to match write_versioninfo.

Additionally, there is an edge case where if the code is installed from a
github zipball, versioning info is missing. Now that we're using this,
there should be virtual no instances where a zipball will be easier or
less cost than an sdist created tarball, all of which should be public and
accessible, but during the transition, we need to account for the codepath.

Change-Id: Icd3fe97c6341bb04da27adc55a85f1ab6b525c46

commit_message:
'Edit' image disabled if image in 'Queued' state

As the 'edit' image/snapshot form reads
the properties of the image, and they are
unavailable while the image is in 'queued'
state, this row action should be hidden
in that case.

Fixes bug 1017867

Change-Id: Ice3a6bc7898cf68d28ab9c27b4173e02913f1a56

commit_message:
Update the sensitive data exception filter bugfix.

Sometimes the pretty DEBUG traceback page wouldn't be
displayed due to an error in the filter. This copies
the code from the final upstream bugfix into Horizon.

When Django 1.4.1 is available we can update to that
and remove this patch.

Fixes bug 1018091.

Change-Id: I73658a27e2303d2ac8840a6f513911dbc4bd4b96

Seems very sensible to me...'}, {'account_id': 1711, 'date': '2012-06-27 01:26:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I doubt if this alone would fix that bug, but in general having calls instead of casts makes code more sequential and easier to reason about. Unless the latency to save is very important, IMHO calls should be in favor instead of casts..'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-06-27 01:36:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

failure looks unrelated'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-27 19:37:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I was under the impression that we should be striving to eliminate all cross-service calls."}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-06-27 19:44:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I'm fine with this. Just a thought, you may want to make sure that any exceptions which can bubble up as a result of this being a call instead of a cast are handled (if there are any)."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-06-27 20:24:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Brian: why? I'm not changing the remote execution logic, I'm just allowing for an action to be taken after the cast finishes.

The cast means that anything we do after the cast (like deal with a failure for example or delete related resources) happens immediately.  This is non-obvious and has lead to hard to find bugs like the one linked above.

For example, without this change, it is possible for a vif to be deallocated before the fixed ip that is attached to it is deleted, which could cause potential problems."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-27 20:33:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Starting gate jobs.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-27 20:33:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

So I feel like this is a silly chain of events that leads up to this, but fixing that is a massive change.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-27 21:22:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build successful

commit_message:
Fixing the project dropdown.

If there was only one project you were
authorized for, it would still show a
dropdown on the nav sidebar. This fixes
that.

Change-Id: If9d92c82688bb5832aebb5d3356598bcf590549e

subject: Make nova list/show behave nicely on instance_type deletion
messages:
[{'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-27 17:33:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-06-27 17:42:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

minor nit:

commit message typo s/instatnce_type/instance_type"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-27 17:48:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/3627/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/4942/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/1139/consoleFull : ABORTED
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/1152/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/6481/consoleFull : SUCCESS
"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-06-27 19:27:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-06-27 19:33:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Vish: Oops.  Fixed.

Johannes: When I ran into this in our environment, I was using novaclient and doing a 'nova list' which would barf and get no results.  After I'd made this fix, I got results just fine.  I didn't check the spec.  It seemed like no matter what the spec said, this should be an acceptable response.. The only alternative is to just completely fail a whole nova list... but more gracefully than just a KeyError being raised and converted to a 500.   I guess another alternative is to not return the instance at all... but that's probably an even worse option.

commit_message:
Make nova list/show behave nicely on instance_type deletion

One shouldn't remove an instance_type from the DB outright... but we should
make the code behave nicely in the rare case.

Fixes bug 1018500

Change-Id: If742070d7982889a56709ae058cd106e3a63114b

commit_message:
Auth token caching on by default. --no_cache to disable. Better bypass support too.

Will use and/or store your Openstack Auth token in the operating
system's keyring if available. Cuts about a 1/2 second off operations.

Change-Id: Ibe2dc0c49baefd23afe3844a78c1df884a4fb7c7

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-24 07:02:23.000000000', 'message': "Fixing Amazon Image Creation

When Amazon disk_format images were created through
Horizon, it would fail as the container_format is
expected to be the same as the disk_format by
Glance, otherwise it can be 'bare'

Fixes bug #1017066

Change-Id: Id8af433e5d37e945244aa30727a0a2ab18e706d9
"}]
commit_message:
Fixing Amazon Image Creation

When Amazon disk_format images were created through
Horizon, it would fail as the container_format is
expected to be the same as the disk_format by
Glance, otherwise it can be 'bare'

Fixes bug #1017066

Change-Id: Id8af433e5d37e945244aa30727a0a2ab18e706d9

Make image.upload notification send up2date metadata

The dictionary passed is not updated with image size, etc.

Fixes bug 1018246

Change-Id: I735d355891fcbd6b1db088b218b8fd808b8908e1

commit_message:
Adds xcp disk resize support

Implements resize image during instance creation.  Fixes bug 1016650.

Selecting a flavor different of m1.tiny for an instance, this bugfix implements  supported when XCP is used. The XCP is related of XenServer described on table below:
XenServer 5.5 == XCP 0.5
XenServer 5.6 == XCP 1.0
XenServer 5.6sp2 == XCP 1.1
XenServer 6.0 == XCP 1.5

Change-Id: I1237d20c37b2e87f8008c13f29d33e5a79a7a721

The first time the user presses ctrl-c, all QueueFunctionThreads will

Change-Id: Ie6927f78726ac1c7998e920cb608682ead10f25b
"}, {'created': '2012-06-27 19:05:24.000000000', 'message': "Make swift exit on ctrl-c.

The first time the user presses ctrl-c, all QueueFunctionThreads will
have abort=True set on them. This will cause them to finish the work
they're doing (e.g. finish uploading the current file) but then ignore
any further work and let the process exit. Also, a notification of
this is written to stderr so the user understands why the process
didn't exit immediately.

Change-Id: Ie6927f78726ac1c7998e920cb608682ead10f25b
"}]
commit_message:
Make swift exit on ctrl-c.

The first time the user presses ctrl-c, all QueueFunctionThreads will
have abort=True set on them. This will cause them to finish the work
they're doing (e.g. finish uploading the current file) but then ignore
any further work and let the process exit. Also, a notification of
this is written to stderr so the user understands why the process
didn't exit immediately.

The second time the user presses ctrl-c, the process will exit
immediately. Any in-progress operations are abandoned.

Change-Id: Ie6927f78726ac1c7998e920cb608682ead10f25b

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-13 22:09:45.000000000', 'message': "Configurable concurrency for swift client.

The 'delete', 'download', and 'upload' commands use multiple threads
for concurrency. However, the number of threads was hardcoded at
10. This patch simply makes those configurable.

For example, if I'm downloading a lot of files but I don't want to
saturate the downstream on my Internet connection, I might choose to
use only 1 or 2 threads for object downloads. Conversely, if I'm
uploading a lot of small files across a fast network, I would want
lots of threads to speed things along.

The default number of threads is 10, so the default behavior is
unchanged.

Change-Id: I64c06741b24ca97fef5ded206d7e898bf5cab3b8
"}, {'created': '2012-06-27 19:31:21.000000000', 'message': "Configurable concurrency for swift client.

The 'delete', 'download', and 'upload' commands use multiple threads
for concurrency. However, the number of threads was hardcoded at
10. This patch simply makes those configurable.

For example, if I'm downloading a lot of files but I don't want to
saturate the downstream on my Internet connection, I might choose to
use only 1 or 2 threads for object downloads. Conversely, if I'm
uploading a lot of small files across a fast network, I would want
lots of threads to speed things along.

The default number of threads is 10, so the default behavior is
unchanged.

Change-Id: I64c06741b24ca97fef5ded206d7e898bf5cab3b8
"}]
commit_message:
Configurable concurrency for swift client.

The 'delete', 'download', and 'upload' commands use multiple threads
for concurrency. However, the number of threads was hardcoded at
10. This patch simply makes those configurable.

For example, if I'm downloading a lot of files but I don't want to
saturate the downstream on my Internet connection, I might choose to
use only 1 or 2 threads for object downloads. Conversely, if I'm
uploading a lot of small files across a fast network, I would want
lots of threads to speed things along.

The default number of threads is 10, so the default behavior is
unchanged.

Change-Id: I64c06741b24ca97fef5ded206d7e898bf5cab3b8

commit_message:
Support sql service catalog backend

* Add KEYSTONE_CATALOG_BACKEND to select 'sql' or 'template'
  'template' is the default
* Add service creation to keystone_data.sh

Rebased and re-submitted

Fixes bug 966457

Change-Id: Id24fbdeba3de11537559e24b72571ec92ab44750

commit_message:
Allow specify tenant:user in user.

We allow having the syntax tenant:user in user since this would make
things easier when switching from auth 1.0 to auth 2.0 and not having to
specify a tenant_name.

In the feature we should use the auth functions from keystoneclient and
be done with those changes, we could then auth by user/tenant-ID.

Change-Id: Ie49748105a678fb9369494e77d41d934d57a39a7

commit_message:
Make CLI exit nonzero on error.

This makes it much easier to detect failure in scripts.

Fixes bug 973557.

Change-Id: Ifd16ffcb7be85e45582095246cc29cfe44e2a173

subject: Refactor 404's into managers & drivers (bug 968519)
messages:
[{'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-04-30 16:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

Hey Dolph - 

I get where you're going with this, and generally like it - but there's a LOT of translation of exceptions happening that seem overcomplicated. Wouldn't it make more sense to assert a contract for the "Driver" class for the individual serverices to raise specific NotFound() exception variations based on the methods, and document that in the docstrings of the Driver class in each of catalog, identity, token, etc?

Some of the translations made perfect sense, but mostly it seemed like a lot of work to enforce an idea that isn't otherwise documented in the code and won't be obvious for others following on.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-04-30 16:34:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

Joe: Need clarification on inline comments.

I didn't think to doc the expected exceptions in identity.Driver, catalog.Driver, token.Driver; They *definitely* need to be revised."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-04-30 18:53:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 494, 'date': '2012-05-03 19:53:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

it seems like the transformations into specific exception types (ServiceNotFound, etc) could be better done in the manager classes, that is mostly what they are for as that same code will be common to all implementations of a given method, if the backends raise different kinds of NotFound we can probably catch multiple types in the manager and just make sure any get turned into specific exceptions"}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-05-04 12:14:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

termie: I like that, will do."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-05-09 13:07:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-05-09 13:16:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I made the suggested changes to the catalog manager to see what it would look like. It definitely simplifies the KVS implementation, but I left the SQL driver alone because it wasn't doing those try/excepts.

To test specific exception types now, I had to instantiate the manager for a few tests in test_backend (`self.catalog_man`) -- which seems kind of awkward, but I'm not sure it's worth setting up a whole separate suite of `test_manager_*` modules, etc? The existing tests could be changed to simply check for generic NotFound's, and then test the manager's translations separately.

Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-24 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

commit_message:
Refactor 404's into managers & drivers (bug 968519)

The goal is to move the responsibility of reference checks away from
controllers and into the underlying managers & drivers, which can
handle the task with equal or greater efficiency.

- Tenant references from create_user/update_user are NOT tested
  due to inconsistencies between backends
- Additional test coverage improvements

Also fixes bug 999209, bug 999608, bug 1006029, bug 1006055, bug 1006287,
bug 1006334, and bug 1006344.

Change-Id: I7de592e7dd4518038436b9a9fdaab559b00a0537

commit_message:
Filter out v1.0 endpoints

- Addresses bug 1014860
- v1.0 endpoints should not be considered valid endpoints
  by python-novaclient
- also ignores other unkown versions (for when 3 comes out)
- includes updated catalog tests

Change-Id: I73bd9b0dbede74ee0d975caa86145219e30262fc

commit_message:
Stop nova_ipam_lib from changing the timeout setting

 * Fixes incorrect logic for when timeout should be used. We
   want to timeout along with dhcp, and release immediately
   without dhcp
 * Also makes ipam_lib release fixed_ips after floating ips, as
   this is the way that the internal network managers do it.
 * Fixes bug 1014769

Change-Id: I687fac314264b8a89da128ed77c02d9b1ca140ff

That suppose to address this use case :

http://pastie.org/4075284

isn't it ?

because that does not seem to work."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-06-12 18:39:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

I'll pound on it some more and see what's going on there."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-06-13 22:38:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Ready For Review

I looked more, and I don't think this is intended to cover the Ctrl-C case.

The aim here was to make sure the client exited when some internal exception happened. For example, take a look at _download_object(): if it gets a ClientException with an HTTP status that isn't 404, it'll re-raise the exception. That causes the QueueFunctionThread to never be empty, and so when download() gets down to the end and waits for the object queue to be empty (line 432-433 in master), that queue will never be empty, and so the main thread will busy-wait forever.

The Ctrl-C hang comes about because the main thread doesn't signal all the other threads to exit; I will address that in a separate patch."}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-06-14 11:30:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

nice catch, thanks for the explanation.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-06-18 16:51:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-06-18 16:53:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Make swift not hang on error.

Before, if a QueueFunctionThread's function raised an exception, then
its thread would log the exception and exit, leaving the rest of the
jobs in the queue and ensuring that the swift client would hang.

Now, the exception is logged and processing continues, so all the
messages get handled eventually and the client exits.

Change-Id: I43d4df212847a2a85732b304de319ea2cce82ddd

commit_message:
update stack.sh due to quantum changes

The following git commit a86c31ba1544528cd8473896076e8b1b4ef14bce
changes the following variables in ovs_quantum_plugin.ini from
(enable-tunneling, local-ip) to enable_tunneling, local_ip).
Therefore the quantum configuration section of stack.sh needs
to also update these variable names.

Fixes bug 1015333

Removes the logic used for plugins.ini which is no
longer needed and adds a mv to copy policy.json

Fixes bug 1015418

Change-Id: Ib4f39b3095bab3db116395e750cef695113340e8
