a) I would prefer leaving reset(0) in if it is available and falling back to the old method, but I could be convinced that it isn't necessary
you could protect it with a if hasattr(virt_dom, 'reset'):

b) inline simplification to restart code."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-06-25 20:08:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-06-25 20:45:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I suppose my thought was to avoid using hasattr as much as possible. I suppose there are cases where you want to add new features but maintain backwards compatibility... in those cases using hasattr makes sense. But given the old method works just fine is there really a compelling reason to have conditional code in place to do both?

Either way I'm fine. Just thought I'd mention it."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-06-25 21:10:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I guess i'm thinking that the reset method is probably more efficient and has less chance of breaking, but as I said, I'm not totally sold on needing it. We could use try/except AttributeError instead of hasattr, or explicitly check libvirt version. I just thought hasattr was the quickest solution.

I think the other concern of not trying to recreate the network is important though."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-06-26 09:23:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

From the POV of a guest OS, there isn't really significant difference between destroy+start, and reset(). As Vish notes probably the most significant difference is the possible re-creation of any host side setup, networking TAP devices / firewall rules being the stuff most relevant to Nova.

My inclination was that it was not worth maintaining 2 different codepaths for new vs old libvirt, but the additional overheads of tearing down & setting up the host side network/firewall config sways my opinion back towards maintaining 2 codepaths for new vs old.

FYI, while hasattr('reset') is sufficient /if/ you assume that the libvirt python bindings are the same version as the libvirt daemon, if a mismatch is possible/likely, then you also need to catch & handle a possible libvirt error with a code of libvirt.VIR_ERR_NO_SUPPORT"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-06-26 14:24:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-06-26 14:28:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Vish: Patchset 2 puts in the hasattr to test for reset(). I also removed the code to recreate the network when reset() isn't supported.

Daniel: I didn't put in code to catch the exception when there is a libvirt/libvirt daemon mismatch. I think we can assume most people are using version that match (or are very close to matching)."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-06-26 14:44:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Personally I would have put the removal of the unused 'network_info' arg in a separate commit, since it is an independent cleanup, but I won't block this change on that minor point."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-26 16:37:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

[{'created': '2012-06-25 16:50:01.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid use of Libvirt reset for hard reboot.

Updates the libvirt connection so that it avoids using reset()
which requires at least libvirt 0.9.7. Instead it uses the older
method of recreating the domain and network information.

This patch also sets the libvirt min version back to 0.9.6.

Fixes LP Bug #1017593.

Change-Id: I6c46c03fad9de11ae3cc814b06dd8e13bb66de2d
'}, {'created': '2012-06-26 14:24:36.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid reset on hard reboot if not supported.

Updates the libvirt connection so that it avoids using virt_dom.reset(0)
when performing a hard reboot if it is not supported.

Libvirt reset requires at least libvirt 0.9.7.

When reset is not supported it uses the older method of recreating the
domain.

This patch also sets the libvirt min version back to 0.9.6.

Fixes LP Bug #1017593.

Change-Id: I6c46c03fad9de11ae3cc814b06dd8e13bb66de2d
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid reset on hard reboot if not supported.

Updates the libvirt connection so that it avoids using virt_dom.reset(0)
when performing a hard reboot if it is not supported.

Libvirt reset requires at least libvirt 0.9.7.

When reset is not supported it uses the older method of recreating the
domain.

This patch also sets the libvirt min version back to 0.9.6.

Fixes LP Bug #1017593.

Change-Id: I6c46c03fad9de11ae3cc814b06dd8e13bb66de2d

commit_message:
Clean up image member db api methods

* Drop image_member_get
* Drop image_member_get_memberships
* Repurpose image_member_find for collection filtering
* Write a db api functional test to cover image_member_find

Change-Id: I7fc17156feac98ba5d22a436aabfbe50114c6c61

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-22 20:28:56.000000000', 'message': 'metadata: cleanup pubkey representation

The previous code provided a '_name' entry in a dict to represent this,
but then appended "=_name" to the key rather than populating _name with
the full value to be rendered.

This just changes the value in '_name' for public key to be '0=keyname'
rather than 'keyname'.  It makes the rendering simpler by just using the
_name.

It also adds a test for this strange behavior of the metadata service.

Change-Id: I3ef67d85354bf7ac8abaaf900ddfdd2e945aa9af

commit_message:
metadata: cleanup pubkey representation

The previous code provided a '_name' entry in a dict to represent
this, but then appended "=_name" to the key rather than populating
_name with the full value to be rendered.

This just changes the value in '_name' for public key to be
'0=keyname' rather than 'keyname'.  It makes the rendering simpler by
just using the
_name.

It also adds a test for this strange behavior of the metadata service.

Change-Id: I3ef67d85354bf7ac8abaaf900ddfdd2e945aa9af

commit_message:
Retry test server launch on failure to listen.

In the functional tests, the registry server intermittently
fails to listen on the expected port, with the strace revealing
an EADDRINUSE error.

We now retry the service launch on a fresh port.

Change-Id: Id2e06a7ae90c4a9aa3ff33c19316ebf854a30e22

commit_message:
Improve filter_scheduler performance

Add 'columns_to_join' keyword arg to instance_get_all() and have the
scheduler host_manager only join 'instance_type'.  It doesn't use
anything else.

Fixes bug 1017769

Change-Id: Ia2c0956d2453f00e26eb89d9496a32ba15d970aa

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-26 02:11:20.000000000', 'message': 'Remove unnecessary queries for network info in notifications

bandwidth_usage() tries to query network info if "not network_info"
when looking at instance['info_cache'].  [] is a valid entry for
network_info (on build)... so don't query network when we see it.

Fixes bug 1017770

Change-Id: Ia7291dbbcc25c04eff16eb048068f879e18f53a4
'}]
commit_message:
Remove unnecessary queries for network info in notifications

bandwidth_usage() tries to query network info if "not network_info"
when looking at instance['info_cache'].  [] is a valid entry for
network_info (on build)... so don't query network when we see it.

Fixes bug 1017770

Change-Id: Ia7291dbbcc25c04eff16eb048068f879e18f53a4

commit_message:
Fixes for probe tests

Updated the imports and added a head_account to the "is the cluster
started yet?" checks. Hopefully this fixes the notorious timing
issues of these tests where auth answers requests just a bit before
the rest of the cluster is ready.

Fixes bug 1014931

Change-Id: Iea1d62db2317560371da49af5e94a0279b646294

commit_message:
Make proxy-logging more like eventlet.posthook

The old use of Eventlet's posthook process meant that responses that
forgot to include content-length or transfer-encoding headers would
get one tacked on, if Eventlet could guess what was probably meant. I
added a bit of that logic into proxy-logging now as we saw some
errors resulting from this.

Fixes Bug #1012714

Change-Id: I671453eaf3704eab814ff12c4625ba7d749cc7ed

Better even that what I had in mind originally :)'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-06-26 15:29:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-06-26 17:15:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Where is the cache management? How do instances get expired from the cache? Where is the watermark that prevents this process from exploding, once it balloons past a certain point?  I don't see any of this in the current patch-set."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-06-26 17:17:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Eric, the wsgi.Request object is what contains the cache, and this object only lives for the duration of a single API request. I don't think there is a need (other than documenting the above statement in a comment) for anything more complicated."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-06-26 17:18:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: No score

devstack failure appears to be transient, but not re-approving since there are -1's.

Eric: The cache exists for the duration of a single request; none of the concerns you state are particularly relevant…"}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-06-26 17:40:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

Good point, changing my review to 0.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-06-26 17:41:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Jay: Thanks... will be addressing your feedback in a second!'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-06-26 18:02:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-06-26 18:03:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Jay: Implemented your suggestions.

Clarified some doc strings and added comments.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-06-26 18:05:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I've looked more closely at this patch, and while Vish mentions caching could be done at the DB layer, I'm also inclined to suggest that a similar implementation to this could be crafted using memoization, instead of this awkward caching strategy.

One flaw with the current approach is that there is a lot of faith put into the state of the request object. If the data isn't cached, it doesn't /get/ cached in the way it would with a memoization-style approach.  Instead, the methods that call req.get_db_instance() or req.get_db_instances() will receive an IndexError exception.  This implementation might be engineered around that, such that an IndexError never actually happens, but that is only true for as long as nobody modifies the behavior (and we keep this in mind and keep track of it during future reviews).  The memoization route would be cleaner and more resilient against breakage."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-26 18:17:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/3435/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/4830/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/1032/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/1040/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/6237/consoleFull : FAILURE
"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-06-26 18:35:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Eric:

That is how I was thinking of implementing the caching in the db layer, but it runs into the problem of how do we make requests for new objects and do we do it specifically?  We could create a new wrapper for some db calls that memoizes and use the memoized version in the core api and the extensions, but It seems like that leads to its own potential gotchas and it might be overengineering slightly.

Do you see a simple way to do the memoization? The best I can come up with is adding a couple of calls to compute_api:
get_memoized and get_all_memoized.

It seems like that gets us most of the way there although we might have to move the filtering that is done into the compute api as well.

Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-06-26 18:56:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I'm not sure that 'memoization' solves our problems here.  The queries being done in extensions are not exactly the same queries as the original ones.  The 'detail' call in particular does an instance_get_all() in the core API... and it may have filters associated with it.  Extensions don't call instance_get_all() again with the same arguments, but they call it with a filter which only returns instances in the set of uuids returned from the original query.  Those calls were about as efficient as they could be.  Extensions could be changed to do an 'instance_get_by_uuid' and you could tie that into the same lookup table as the instance_get_all(), sure... and that's probably what I would do if we implemented this as generic caching in the DB layer.  It would take too long to try to implement all of the filtering capabilities of instance_get_all() to use a cache.  But all of that's not 'memoization', right?  That's just 'caching'.  I don't want to get caught up in the technicalities, though.  I just had an immediate need to remove unnecessary DB calls to speed up things like 'nova list'.

This is a patch that I'm using internally for now to solve a specific case.  Vish was interested in seeing it to solve something similar and it gives some immediate benefit to trunk.  I'm hesitant to do anything in the DB layer because there's loads of other problems there that need to be solved... Ie, I feel like the current DB code needs to change completely and implementing a cache there right now might be a waste of time at this point."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-06-26 19:14:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I'm not suggesting that this patch be immediately replaced with DB memoization or caching as Vish appears to suggest.

Instead, I'm suggesting that calls to get_db_instance(s) should effectively be calls to _get_server(s).  Then, _get_servers(s) would first check for an existing cached response, returning if it exists. Otherwise, the method continues, caches, and returns (as the patch currently does)"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-06-26 19:35:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Ok, yeah.  That makes a lot of sense... although as I look, I'm seeing that these classes to do not inherit from the servers.py:Controller class.

Not sure offhand if there's any side effects by changing them..."}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-06-26 19:48:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

This is a great "helps us now" alternative to a true db caching layer which will take loads more bike shed painting to achieve.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-06-26 21:07:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I think I'm fine with this for now. If someone comes up with a better memoization/caching strategy and proposes it I have no problem with it, but this definitely helps with performance for now."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-27 15:23:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: No score

Starting gate jobs.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-06-27 15:23:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Remove extra DB calls for instances from OS API extensions

Allow the core API to store DB results so that extensions can use data
already retrieved within the same API request...eliminating extra
expensive DB calls.  This implements storing of instances only, so far.

Fixes bug 1017756

Change-Id: I98a2e3323f5ea69ab9e7470f95d821790510989e

[{'created': '2012-06-25 22:48:49.000000000', 'message': "Re-factor instance DB creation

This patch speeds up the DB creation process considerably in deployments
with a considerable amount of instances.  It also cleans up a lot of the
code which ends up creating the instance DB record.

The biggest improvement in this patch is removing unnecessary joins in
security_groups DB calls.  This also reduces the number of DB calls
needed to create an instance DB record in general.

Side effect of this patch is the default 'display_name' for an instance
when it (or hostname) is not specified is now 'Server <uuid>' vs
'Server <id>'.  Because of the use of 'id', it required creating the DB
record, then updating the record later after we new the 'id'.  This is
gone.

Fixes bug 1017722

Change-Id: I9b7d48644a7abe075545c2c11399351b6a37939c

commit_message:
Re-factor instance DB creation

This patch speeds up the DB creation process considerably in deployments
with a considerable amount of instances.  It also cleans up a lot of the
code which ends up creating the instance DB record.

The biggest improvement in this patch is removing unnecessary joins in
security_groups DB calls.  This also reduces the number of DB calls
needed to create an instance DB record in general.

Side effect of this patch is the default 'display_name' for an instance
when it (or hostname) is not specified is now 'Server <uuid>' vs
'Server <id>'.  Because of the use of 'id', it required creating the DB
record, then updating the record later after we new the 'id'.  This is
gone.

Fixes bug 1017722

Change-Id: I9b7d48644a7abe075545c2c11399351b6a37939c

commit_message:
fix bug lp:1011087.

when periodic task update driver status,if libvirt is down,in this
state,nova-compute can not execute create,terminate instance task.
now,we just stop nova-compute from running,and send notifications.

Change-Id: Ic37dba64069b157a5a99b497eb00e7b497b94f68

commit_message:
Removes inappliable swauth setting from swift doc

The documentation by default refers to the OpenStack Identity
Service, so moved a swauth specific reference to a note at the base
of the article.

fixes bug 997069

Change-Id: Ibdc1d6c84f711ffd9ca0eedc8368664d3e672310

commit_message:
fix keystone endpoint example for swift

fixes bug 1002296
The keystone endpoint creation example was inconsistent and just
wrong. Fixed it up so it now uses the correct port, URLs and
the command matches the output.

commit_message:
Add action extensions to support nova integration.

 * Adds VolumeActions extension to support key functions
    described in blueprint volume-decoupling
 * Adds snapshot translations to APIs
 * Should be back in sync with 7992
 * blueprint compat-extensions
 * sleepsonthefloor: Moved added snapshot attributes to extension, added tests
 * sleepsonthefloor: Lock pep8==1.1 in tox.ini

Change-Id: I9c6118cd434ca8b275d2386546923f932420b975

commit_message:
Documents vncserver_listen flag when used with live migrations

Live migration breaks if vncserver_listen is set to a specific host
IP address.

Documentation based on this comment from the openstack-operators
mailing list:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-operators/2012-June/000965.html

See also comments in bug 1009974.

Change-Id: I21b1d3eb5380effda3e2bfcd4f3ea15ea43f096a

commit_message:
Allow access to metadata server '/' without IP check

Allow access to '/' of metadata server to get version information without
checking source IP, which was how previous release behave.

Fix bug 1017759.

Change-Id: I3edc2d3808b0ebb2064513a59e6a3fc9e212b283

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-25 16:12:15.000000000', 'message': "fix libvirt get_memory_mb_total() with xen

Commit 5b93a576 failed to remove the 'staticmethod'
decorator from the method, to allow it to access
object variables.

Also move the platform check to thespecific clause
that needs it.

Change-Id: I565eda78f6c468cf6bd227756cfc068725069218
"}, {'created': '2012-06-25 22:52:14.000000000', 'message': "fix libvirt get_memory_mb_total() with xen

Commit 5b93a576 failed to remove the 'staticmethod'
decorator from the method, to allow it to access
object variables.

Also there is no need to have the libvirt getInfo() call
be xen specific.  In the LXC/QEMU/UML drivers this call
uses GNULIB's physmem module, which is cross-OS portable.

Change-Id: I565eda78f6c468cf6bd227756cfc068725069218
"}]
commit_message:
fix libvirt get_memory_mb_total() with xen

Commit 5b93a576 failed to remove the 'staticmethod'
decorator from the method, to allow it to access
object variables.

Also there is no need to have the libvirt getInfo() call
be xen specific.  In the LXC/QEMU/UML drivers this call
uses GNULIB's physmem module, which is cross-OS portable.

Change-Id: I565eda78f6c468cf6bd227756cfc068725069218

commit_message:
Reorganisation of Dashboard install chapter

In Horizon, databases are only used for session storage, for which
there are a few options. The install doc used memcache for the session
 cache, but also asked users to install a MySQL database, which was
unnecessary.

This change creates a new section, based on the horizon developer
docs which explains all of the options for session storage in
OpenStack Dashboard. It moves the redundant MySQL configuration to
that section, and references it in a note.

This change also attempts to improve section-leveling throughout the
chapter.

Patch set 2 fixes a typo (depooyment) and removes a <title> element
from the ch_installdashboard.xml as it caused a duplicate display of
the title text.

fixes bug 997347

Change-Id: I9d47adc06c48eac14dc1e9f50b1b0bb133bd3f8d

configuration reference page in stable/essex

This one line change adds the include that fixes that.

fixes bug 1016027

An alternate view might be that the comments there could be not migrated at all to ensure fresh, relevant content ...

Anyway, you're the expert! :)"}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-06-23 15:31:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Well, I thought about that, but these comments are all new since Essex, so there aren't too many yet, and they are mostly based on the apt guide. It's probably three or four comments we're looking at migrating, I believe. So the split is safe to do now (rather than waiting until Folsom or some such) and it's impossible to keep (and continue to build) the old comments with a single pom file. commit_message:
Creates new disqus ID for each install guide - yum and apt.

This change should avoid the mind-bending associated with knowing
which distro a commenter is commenting about on a single page.

However it also means all old comment threads will not display on
a given page for the install guide.

I'll see what I can do to migrate threads but it does get tricky since
threads-per-page cannot be migrated to two separate pages.

Change-Id: Ifc768a7b0b04880af0e8086e9a913e3650cf4aa4

[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-26 19:51:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-06-26 19:51:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for dealing with this contentious and tricky issue.
I have looked at the code and it looks good. I do not feel like I have the relevant knowledge of Xen XCP to approve. I would prefer that this is done by the guys who are familiar with this.
My humble apologies.'}, {'account_id': 2350, 'date': '2012-06-26 19:51:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Who is the "Xen/XCP guy"? :)'}, {'account_id': 4362, 'date': '2012-06-26 19:51:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I guess I and Maru are the XCP/XS guys around here.

The patch is perfect, and indeed my concerns are not about the patch, but rather about running python26 in dom0.
I understand this approach has been tested on large deployments, and in principle I agree python24 and python26 could coexist.
However, several XCP/XS users would regard the burden of managing two python environments as the four-letter acronym which resembles the name of a greek bread...
Also, this would probably be unacceptable for people running commercially supported versions of XenServer.
Please don't take this as me being stubborn :)

Summarizing, I am not against running python26 on dom0. However, the current patch will make this a requirement for the ovs plugins, and I am not extremely keen on it.

I would be happy to keep the discussion running and possibly contribute with more than a review to try and sort out this issue."}, {'account_id': 4381, 'date': '2012-06-26 19:51:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Oks :D. I'll split this patch and leave only the install without python2.6, so we can keep talking about python2.6 on XS later :D"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-26 19:51:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/559/ : SUCCESS

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-python26/209/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-python27/209/ : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 4381, 'date': '2012-06-26 19:51:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4381, 'date': '2012-06-26 19:51:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-26 19:51:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/589/ : SUCCESS

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-python26/238/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-python27/238/ : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-06-26 19:51:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Juliano,
thanks for taking into account my comment!'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-06-26 19:51:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: No score

Thanks Bob for your specialist feedback.

I'm therefore holding off my approval until Bob's comments are addressed."}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-06-26 19:51:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I don't see any issues with the code changes themselves, but, before approving, I'd like to understand the status of the three different make targets. 

- Although I'm not setup to fully test it, it does look like "make agent-dist-xen-python26" should produce an RPM that may work on Xen XCP. I attempted to test this on Fedora 17 by commenting out the yum line and replacing 2.6 with 2.7, and ran into rpm build errors due to the .pyo and .pyc files being unpackaged. I'll assume you've tested this on the environment its intended for, and it works there.

- It looks like "make agent-dist-xen" should do the same thing, but using the native python 2.4 instead of 2.6. Is the RPM generated in the case expected to work on Xen XCP? Can you clarify whether the openstack-common python 2.4 compatibility issues mentioned in the bug report were real and have been avoided or fixed?

- Finally, "make agent-dist", as originally cited in the bug report, seems to still create a tarball that contains the agent python module itself, but none of the other python modules it now depends on. What purpose does this make target serve? Should it be removed?'}, {'account_id': 2350, 'date': '2012-06-26 19:51:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

For now Juliano is making it to work with python 2.4 by default but the code for python2-6 is done as well. The default should be changed (or not) depending on our decision.'}, {'account_id': 4381, 'date': '2012-06-26 19:51:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Bob and Salvatori,

1 - I didn't try build it on Fedora :(. The issue could be some macro issue with a newer rpm version from fedora. I've tested on XCP and XS with a clean server install before each build.

2 - In this case we will have the agent installed with python2.4 and it won't work either but will install on XS/XCP. To fix the issue definitively we should use the option above, use python2.6 and be happy. I've added this option following the Salvatori concern to not force anyone to use python2.6, so if someone fix every issue from quantum.common to run with python2.4, or we split the code to work with python2.4 in the future it is ready to use. 

3 - I'll remove it."}, {'account_id': 4381, 'date': '2012-06-26 19:51:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-26 19:51:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

This change added the feature to package and install the ovs-quantum-agent inside XS and XCP,
added a option on Makefile to gen and install using python2.6 ( by default it will use 2.4 )

Change-Id: I8860d7dcb7e7b74125784cb0f33c6ca03b37702b
'}, {'created': '2012-06-26 19:51:14.000000000', 'message': 'Bug #1012418 - quantum agent for OVS does not install properly on Xen XCP

Changed ovs plugin to use python2.6 from EPEL instead of use python2.4 from XS nd XCP,
this changed wont break anything from system (the python binary from EPEL is called python2.6),
the python2.4 from XS and XCP keep untouched and default for the system

It also fix #994831, #995278, #994774

Change-Id: I8860d7dcb7e7b74125784cb0f33c6ca03b37702b
'}]
commit_message:
Bug #1012418 - quantum agent for OVS does not install properly on Xen XCP

This change added the feature to package and install the ovs-quantum-agent inside XS and XCP,
added an option on Makefile to gen and install using python2.6 ( by default it will use 2.4 )

Change-Id: I8860d7dcb7e7b74125784cb0f33c6ca03b37702b

commit_message:
Remove paste configuration details to a seperate file.
blueprint use-common-cfg

In addition this ensures that the cisco extension units are working
with the common cfg code.

Change-Id: I8c1f81e295e7ed593f0b58885efeeb15339b7733

thanks!  All fixed, I think.'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-06-26 18:59:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-06-26 18:59:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Sorry, missed this first time through ...

openstack/common/notifier/test_notifier.py should only live in the tests. I think we can fully qualify notifier handlers can't we? If not, we should mock the method to store the notifications in memory."}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-06-26 18:59:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Moved.

But, now that I think of it, that file isn't used by common, but is used in some nova tests.  And, the 'common' dir in nova doesn't include the common tests.  So this file needs to either stay where it is or get duplicated into each project...

Leaving it where it is seems, maybe, most reasonable."}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-06-26 18:59:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-06-26 18:59:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-06-26 18:59:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-06-26 18:59:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-06-26 18:59:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Hmm, yeah, that's a problem. But one we'll have to live with."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-06-26 18:59:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

It would be nice if the logging and notifier stuff were split apart into 2 patches, since they are separate things.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-06-26 18:59:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-06-26 18:59:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Developing across project-boundaries is a drag.'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-06-26 18:59:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

> It would be nice if the logging and notifier stuff were 
> split apart into 2 patches, since they are separate things.

I agree that it would be nice, and my first attempt at this work involved two separate patches.

As it turns out, though, the logging code in Nova depends on notifications, and the notification code in Nova depends on logging.  So to apply as separate steps I would have to remove code from logging and notification, commit those two patches, and then commit two more patches to replace the previously removed code, ultimately getting us exactly what you see here.

Once down that road a bit a started to feel silly, since the ultimate goal is a transplant of both features, more or less intact.  Hence the monster patch you see here.'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-06-26 18:59:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-06-26 18:59:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-06-26 18:59:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Approved

Mondo-patch it is, then.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-26 18:59:20.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-26 18:59:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-openstack-common-merge/112/ : SUCCESS'}]

This code is migrated from Nova, and will soon replace it.

XenServer 6.0 == XCP 1.5

commit_message:
Adds xcp disk resize support

Implements resize image during instance creation.  Fixes bug 1016650.

Selecting a flavor different of m1.tiny for an instance, this bugfix implements  supported when XCP is used. The XCP is related of XenServer described on table below:
XenServer 5.5 == XCP 0.5
XenServer 5.6 == XCP 1.0
XenServer 5.6sp2 == XCP 1.1
XenServer 6.0 == XCP 1.5

Change-Id: I45a7861967681b63dbf142152379d4be3c548e84

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-20 19:45:36.000000000', 'message': "Make `swift-get-nodes -a` show all handoffs.

Commit 95786e5 made swift-get-nodes only output N handoff nodes, where
N is the ring's replica count. This change leaves that behavior in
place as the default, but adds the option -a/--all to print all the
handoff nodes.

This is handy if you're consuming the output with a script, e.g. if
you're doing some analysis of the distribution of primary+handoff
nodes for a particular set of things.

Change-Id: Ie0253575bb21ccf25559a1c5fd20570a58a2d9fa
"}]
commit_message:
Make `swift-get-nodes -a` show all handoffs.

Commit 95786e5 made swift-get-nodes only output N handoff nodes, where
N is the ring's replica count. This change leaves that behavior in
place as the default, but adds the option -a/--all to print all the
handoff nodes.

This is handy if you're consuming the output with a script, e.g. if
you're doing some analysis of the distribution of primary+handoff
nodes for a particular set of things.

Change-Id: Ie0253575bb21ccf25559a1c5fd20570a58a2d9fa

commit_message:
Add python-*client documentation links to dev page

This change adds links to developer documentation for the
nova, openstack, swift, glance, keystone, cinder, and quantum clients

It creates a new section in the table on
http://docs.openstack.org/developer

Patch set 2 adds http://docs.openstack.org/developer/ to each href.

fixes bug 1015184

Change-Id: I852ae54c7b8e01727802e1025aba847544317709

subject: WIP: Make XenAPI more tolerant to unexpected shutdowns
messages:
[{'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-05-10 20:14:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not merge

WIP for now'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-05-10 20:25:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

NIce!

Quick first pass, will revisit in a bit."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-05-10 20:27:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

A couple of notes:

I'm not a fan of the RPC changes I've made. Part of being able to start tasks over again is remembering to start the task over again. This patch leans on the RPC code to delay the ACK until after the processing of the message is done. Unfortunately, we need to ACK the message in a worker thread, which complicates things. It's also not an option with 0mq.

It only implements idempotency for the create and delete paths right now.

Some changes were necessary in the compute manager to not allocate the network multiple times as well as not move the instance to ERROR if the instance already exists (this probably still needs work to make sure it continues on a semi-built instance).

It's kind of weird to bind instance and network_info to the new classes, but not session and context. instance in particular is used so often, most of the code pulls it into a local variable."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-05-10 20:31:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (5 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-05-10 20:36:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-05-10 20:41:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-05-10 21:01:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

One other note too. This doesn't handle multiple dom0 XenAPI tasks very well. For instance, if we initiate a dom0 task to copy an image from glance, restart nova-compute quickly, it will initiate another dom0 task to copy an image from glance, which will likely run concurrently with the first one.

This is probably a difficult situation to get into. There are a variety of long running dom0 tasks that could potentially cause problems, like a variety of agent related communication but also snapshots and maybe others.

A possible solution would be to change all dom0 XenAPI tasks to be asynchronous, set a name-label (or other_config) we could understand, then acquire the instance semaphore on startup while waiting for those tasks to complete. That would allow any dom0 tasks to complete running before any new driver methods get called to operate on that instance."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-05-13 03:16:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-05-13 03:20:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

This is still a WIP. Almost all of the unit tests pass right now. The last one is because of a change in behavior. Failures to create an instance won't cleanup anything anymore. That's left for when the instance is deleted now. I prefer this behavior since it allows the failed build to be inspected for troubleshooting purposes, but it is a change in behavior.

I haven't had a chance to properly test these latest changes because of some problems with my testing setup and being pressured for time with my upcoming trip.

It's likely some more cleanup and perhaps some more bugs will need to be fixed before this ready, but I wanted to get my latest code up."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-05-21 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
WIP: Make XenAPI more tolerant to unexpected shutdowns

Implements blueprint xenapi-idempotency

If nova-compute is stopped (either by the process being killed or
the system crashing) then it will forget what tasks it is currently
working on leaving tasks partially done. This patch switches the
XenAPI driver over to being idempotent to allow tasks to be started
again when nova-compute is restarted.

Change-Id: If8172b918715f0681669418b5d9d37e05724194f

commit_message:
Network deletion and subnet creation bug fixes
bug 1017395

1. When a subnet is created the network id is validated
2. when a network is deleted - if a subnet or port is defined then
the opertaion fails

Change-Id: I746d0f4994c539a908df0220465d753bc3eb8e04

commit_message:
Add missing gettextutils imports

This change fixes a problem we found in the ceilometer
test suite under Python 2.6. The name '_' is not defined
globally, so nose reports import errors trying to scan
the modules changed here.

Change-Id: Ie94cc4effba457342e25f991cf481fc40a1d8cf3

commit_message:
Make tgtadm the default iscsi user-land helper.

Most modern Linux distrobutions have tgtadm as their
default iscsi user-land helper. This includes Ubuntu,
Fedora, RHEL, SuSe, and others.

Make it default for nova as well. No change is
required for devstack since its the default as well.

Change-Id: I3f5204f08bfd9ef41eda2df7aa6bb35559516213
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Add support for tag based versioning.

Versions driven by git.
If the current revision is tagged, then that's the version cut.
If not, for post-versioning, the current version is the tag plus an count of the
revs since the tag.
For pre-versioning, it's the logic that's in create-tarball.sh.
Additionally, a versioninfo file is added to the tree so that pkg-resources
can find out what the version is.

Change-Id: I5991345735fa14666305538c556b519160b02b4b

commit_message:
Fixes bug #953132

Docs for Essex need LDAP with Keystone configuration to be documented
Rework of the LDAP presentation around Keystone : new reference table

Patch set adds xml:id to the new sections so it'll build.

Patch set 3 uses "exampledomain" instead of "younglogic" for the domain
name and fixes typos (exmaple).

Also rebased against stable/essex.

Change-Id: I0c964785bba2f3a58d326cf8a685a87c23f04521

Fixes bug 988139

All new lines (\r, \n) are removed from input
when importing a keypair. This is done as sometimes
a user copies the public key from terminal, with
new lines in it. As new lines are not allowed in
a public key, so they are stripped.

Change-Id: If526bf081448e315f3518d7ecd2689ec816b77a7
'}]
commit_message:
Removed new lines when importing a keypair

Fixes bug 988139

All new lines (\r, \n) are removed from input
when importing a keypair. This is done as sometimes
a user copies the public key from terminal, with
new lines in it. As new lines are not allowed in
a public key, so they are stripped.

Change-Id: If526bf081448e315f3518d7ecd2689ec816b77a7

Nice find on the fake.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-06-21 09:30:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I rather wonder, what is point of having this configuration variable at all ? As a person deploying Nova, reading the description of that config option gives me zero useful information on which to decide whether to enable or disable it. So if we, as upstream developers, think nonblocking execution is important, then we should just enable it unconditionally & do away with the config option completely.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-06-21 09:39:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'account_id': 1711, 'date': '2012-06-21 12:01:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Daniel,

This feature is made configurable because it's a desirable feature, but not well tested in the field. When we implemented this close to the Essex release deadline, this (making it optional and default disabled) felt like the right way to do it. Setting it default to true is roughly equivalent to what you said to make it always on, but have a fall back option to bail quickly. I think in the future G release it might make sense to get rid of the option (to be always enabled). Thanks."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-06-21 12:09:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

IMHO, if we think we have sufficient testing time to justify making this the default for Folsom, then we ought to be fine without needing to retain the config option. Config options like this one are a bad idea in general, because the option that is not the default will inevitably bit-rot through lack of any real usage/testing. It is a shame this change was not made immediately after Essex branched off.'}, {'account_id': 1711, 'date': '2012-06-21 13:10:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Daniel, I agree with you that having too many config options is a bad thing. But making it enabled by default seems to an inevitable step towards always enabled. Or you are suggesting that we skip ahead?'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-06-21 14:08:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: No score

I think we should remove the config option now since there is sufficient testing time for this before release, but I'll withdraw my NACK, and let some other reviewer cast a deciding vote on it"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-21 20:23:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

Starting gate jobs.'}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2012-06-21 20:23:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Fixes code sample in "Getting the API Endpoint"

fixes bug 987624
The code sample in "Getting the API Endpoint URL" had a number of
errors, such as missing auth node, incorrect use of variables etc
This patch fixes that so it should actually work

Patch set 2 adds auth wrapper to all locations in both the xml and mdown document,
plus fixes a "you password" typo.

I think this auth wrapper is needed for Trystack also so ignore my previous comment
about a note needed for diablo v essex clouds.

Patch set 3 fixes the end curly braces (need 3 not 4) and adds a note to address
the empty service catalaog that template-backed clouds return.

Change-Id: I57d055c9a63db73f6b8fb4b59ccdaf36b98e4a19

'}, {'account_id': 2458, 'date': '2012-06-23 06:17:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-06-23 14:54:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Do not merge

Two problems:

1. A major one: PEP8 check doesn't pass:

    horizon/usage/tables.py:53:1: [E302] expected 2 blank lines, found 1

2. An UI issue. When the object doesn't have instance_id, then the function for the link returns None. However this leads to some unexpected behavior - if a Column object has a link, we do:

        if self.link is not None:
            self.classes.append('anchor')

a css class anchor is appended to the <td>. However, we actually do not have a link for that element, and the name of the instance lacks a padding value, and looks bad - see screehshot: http://db.tt/h29WJvOI

I've looked at the code and solving this is not trivial. The <td> is rendered before the link value, and the 'anchor' class is applied to it before we know it is None. So a quick fix could be to return some a link to all project instance for example..."}, {'account_id': 1941, 'date': '2012-06-23 18:40:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Tihomir:

Issue#1: I'll add the extra line

Issue#2: This was caused by a recent change in the Column class. Instead of having a workaround here for the padding issue, it should be treated as a regression and fixed in the Column class as the problem would come up in other places as well.For example: horizon/dashboards/nova/access_and_security/floating_ips/tables.py"}, {'account_id': 1941, 'date': '2012-06-23 18:52:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Logged a bug 1016954 to track the UI issue.'}, {'account_id': 1941, 'date': '2012-06-24 03:26:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2458, 'date': '2012-06-24 03:30:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Fix Project Overview link to use instance_id

Fixes Bug #1003299

Tenant Usage API has been updated to include
instance_id in the response (bug 1003093). The
link has been updated to used instance_id.

Change-Id: I9d5fcf120b1e5966a5e019e5b17dea7806f20650

commit_message:
vm state and task state management

partially implements bp task-management
fixes bug 997867

also see http://wiki.openstack.org/VMState

Refactored the following API/state:
* rebuild
* migrate
* resize
* start
* stop
* delete
* soft delete
* rework sync_power_state in compute/manager.

fix broken tests, add transition diagram in dot

Change-Id: I3c5a97508a6dad7175fba12828bd3fa6ef1e50ee

commit_message:
XenAPI: Fixes Bug 1012878

Launching an instance when the image is not cached fails since
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/7971/, because the change tries
to set the nova_disk_type key in _create_cached_image, but that
is already set in create_vdi

Change-Id: I5eeb1558acf894cc7cd2eea5fd0fb1cdd673b83c

commit_message:
Remove unknown shutdown kwarg in call to vmops._destroy

Fixes bug 1017562

Also, _destroy will now intelligently shutdown the VM first, so need
to do that in vm_vdi_cleaner.py anymore

Change-Id: I8c1e3aa8ecb98ed3c19ab4b8fa072b7fa8e5618f

[{'created': '2012-06-24 05:28:23.000000000', 'message': "Support --os-endpoint-type in glanceclient.

Bug: 993993

* glanceclient/shellp.py
  OpenStackImagesShell.get_base_parser(): Parse --os-endpoint-type
  argument. Default to one defined in os.environ.
  OpenStackImagesShell._authenticate(): Define endpoint type based
  on command line argument. Use 'publicURL', if it's not specified
  in command line and also not defined in os.environ.
  OpenStackImagesShell.main(): Pass this value to authenticate.

Change-Id: I0c0cde5212198eec2a7d75fb2a7cad1cde048c7c
"}]
commit_message:
Support --os-endpoint-type in glanceclient.

Bug: 993993

* glanceclient/shellp.py
  OpenStackImagesShell.get_base_parser(): Parse --os-endpoint-type
  argument. Default to one defined in os.environ.
  OpenStackImagesShell._authenticate(): Define endpoint type based
  on command line argument. Use 'publicURL', if it's not specified
  in command line and also not defined in os.environ.
  OpenStackImagesShell.main(): Pass this value to authenticate.

Change-Id: I0c0cde5212198eec2a7d75fb2a7cad1cde048c7c

commit_message:
Standardize logger instantiation

Use LOG for variable name and __name__ for logger name. Also
document this fact in HACKING.rst

Fixes bug 1015685

Change-Id: I0d9d80bef66197a28ed3d650f17859202048d776

commit_message:
Refactor vm_vdi_cleaner.py connection use

cleanup_instance() would fail because of using old get_connection().
This refactors everything to use XenAPIDriver().

Fixes bug 1017282

Change-Id: I8822f322bb8f60e5992afbe1feb45c0f4fffc893

Hmm, it's a real shame to have a new review for this since there was a bunch of useful discussion on I584a2f5c7507a8ce3a76b8c0f192ca12b69f1e8f"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-20 20:18:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(6 inline comments)

Looks great Thierry!

Main thing to consider is whether using cfg would be good and whether making the config file arg optional would be better for compat with existing nova.conf files

The comments in wrapper.py are just stylistic suggestions"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-06-20 21:13:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I like Mark's suggestion. It means we can do without a conf in most cases. I guess my only concern is that right now nova-rootwrap doesn't have any openstack dependencies which gives it a low surface area for exploits. Perhaps the common.cfg isn't too nasty of a dependency though."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-06-21 09:12:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

It's actually a bit unsafe to have a default value for the filters search path:

The security model around rootwrap is built on explicit configuration, starting with the sudoers line pointing to a safe rootwrap.conf, which points to safe filter directories. Allowing to bypass rootwrap.conf means inserting in the security model a default set of directories which may or may not be secure locations. This significantly weakens the model.

As an example, if the default value is to look into /usr/share/nova/filters and /etc/nova/rootwrap.d, this is unsafe in distributions that do not have /etc/nova/rootwrap.d since someone non-root could potentially create that directory. Forcing every distribution to explicitly specify the path is actually a security feature :)

So actually the change I consider doing now is to not list any directory at all in the path= of the default rootwrap.conf file !"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-06-21 09:24:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (3 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-06-21 09:47:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-21 10:12:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> It's actually a bit unsafe to have a default value for the filters search path

Summary of the concern is that some distros may have /etc/nova or /usr/share/nova writeable by users other than root. By forcing distros to write their own config file, you make sure they don't make that mistake.

Doesn't ring true to me - no sane distro should have the writeable perms open on those dirs anyway. If /etc/nova was writable and only /etc/nova/nova.conf exists, you could write /etc/nova/nova-api.conf and overwrite any settings in nova.conf.

IMHO, the advantage of not breaking existing Essex configuration outweighs the concern"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-06-21 10:30:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I know at least one "distribution" of openstack that makes /etc/nova owned by the nova user. And rightly so: this doesn't break any security barrier (the nova user is already very much owning that configuration anyway). The issue here is that we use /etc/nova for two very different security domains (nova and root). And I wouldn't have the security of the whole root escalation system rely on the fact that no distro would ever make /etc/nova owned by nova.

Alternatively, I suggest we use a separate /etc/nova-rootwrap directory for all that, for which I'd agree nobody has good reason to ever make that non-root-owned. That would neatly separate the two security domains, at the expense of some added complexity.

Then I could agree with you that backward compatibility outweighs the extra complexity.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-06-21 10:49:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Errr... actually letting the old configuration work would create a giant security hole. sudoers allowing "nova-rootwrap" without enforcing the first parameter to be the config file would let the caller specify any configuration file, which breaks the security model entirely.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-06-21 11:05:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> I know at least one "distribution" of openstack that makes /etc/nova owned by the nova user.
> And rightly so: this doesn't break any security barrier (the nova user is already very much 
> owning that configuration anyway). The issue here is that we use /etc/nova for two very 
> different security domains (nova and root).

I can see that the nova user needs to be able to read files in that directory, but what does
Nova actually need write access for ? AFAICT, there's no need for the nova user to have more
than just read permissions.

> And I wouldn't have the security of the whole root escalation system rely on the fact
> that no distro would ever make /etc/nova owned by nova.

I think it is pretty reasonable to expect distros to configure their packages suitably,
if Nova install docs make it clear what the security requirements are for a secure
deployment.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-06-21 12:09:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-06-21 12:14:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Patch set 3 addresses stylistic suggestions in wrapper.py, as well as handles the case of bad/missing configuration file.

For the rest:
* We can't support running nova-rootwrap without a config file, as it means the caller is in control of the optional config file (rather than it being enforced in sudoers). Ping me on IRC if you want me to explain why in more details.
* If you don't need to support default values, use of cfg sounds overkill and increases the quantity of code run as root for no obvious gain"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-21 12:23:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/3243/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/4640/ : UNSTABLE
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/842/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/850/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/5750/ : SUCCESS
"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-06-21 12:25:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-21 12:28:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Cool. A few last things to consider re: cfg ...

1) If we use [DEFAULT] as the section name, it allows us the option to switch to cfg in future if we want. IMHO, having a different section name from other OpenStack config is arbitrary.

2) cfg has native support for parsing lists, but it uses ',' as the separator - can we use the same separator here?

3) multistr is probably a better option here, i.e.

  filter_dir = /usr/share/nova/rootwrap
  filter_dir = /etc/nova/rootwrap.d

rather than:

  filter_dirs = /usr/share/nova/rootwrap,/etc/nova/rootwrap.d

but you can't implement that with ConfigParser"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-21 12:37:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Oh, and on the "enforcing the first parameter" parameter thing, I guess the only way to fix that would be:

  nova ALL = (root) NOPASSWD: /usr/bin/nova-rootwrap -- *

and then e.g.

  cmd = shlex.split(FLAGS.root_helper) + ['--'] + list(cmd)

i.e. people would need to updat their sudo config, but not their nova.conf

I was about to say "meh, that doesn't help" but actually ... it's quite unlikely essex users would have modified /etc/sudoers.d/nova so it would be updated fine with a package update, but it's highly likely people will have modified nova.conf'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-21 12:38:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/3244/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/4641/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/843/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/851/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/5751/ : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-06-21 12:46:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-06-21 12:59:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Mark: right, so we could:
- Only require changing the sudoers invocation
- Avoid shipping rootwrap.conf
- Default to filters_path=/usr/share/nova/rootwrap

The drawback is that when someone wants to change an option to rootwrap.conf, they now have to:

- create rootwrap.conf from scratch with secure permissions
- update /etc/sudoers.d/nova with the location of the file
- update nova.conf to point to it as well

Since we'll be pushing more and more options to rootwrap.conf, and we would require plug-in builders to touch it, that sounds highly inconvenient, compared to:

- edit existing rootwrap.conf

I think requiring package upgrade to update root_helper is a one-time Essex->Folsom cost (mainly to packagers), compared to a forever PITA for all our users the first time they want to change nova-rootwrap options."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-21 13:00:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/3246/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/4643/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/845/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/853/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/5753/ : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-21 16:38:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Ok, looking good to me except it needs a rebase onto Ib362c913b809f7601a9a4faedede89b22794dfb7"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-06-21 18:05:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Thierry,

Looks good to me... and seems to work fine.

Minor nit:

I suppose I'd prefer to call the source directory rootwrap.d and default the location in rootwrap.conf to /etc/nova/rootwrap.d first. I suppose distros can go there own way in this regard though. Not a big deal.

Mark: Good catch on this needing a rebase with the SLES changes. Waiting on that to approve."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-06-22 13:36:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-22 13:50:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me

commit_message:
Move rootwrap filters definition to config files

Move rootwrap filters definition from being defined within Nova
code to being defined in configuration files to facilitate pluging-in
new rootwrap commands.

Transition notes:
* nova-rootwrap now requires an additional (first) parameter pointing
  to the root-owned rootwrap.conf file, sudoers needs to be updated
  to specify that ("nova-rootwrap /etc/nova/rootwrap.conf *")
* Packagers should ship {compute,network,volume}.filters inside a
  directory listed in rootwrap.conf rather than shipping
  nova/rootwrap/{compute,network,volume}.py
* Filter definitions now only support strings. The KillFilter (which was
  using arrays as parameters) was modified and the tests updated.

Implements bp nova-rootwrap-pluggable-filters

Corresponding devstack change needs to land first, so that tests pass:
https://review.openstack.org/8842

Change-Id: I2350154cd8057bd57926ed542de035626f7de37d

Cleans up Horizon's JavaScript to make it properly modular and
well-organized.

Adds unit tests written in QUnit for some of the JS modules
as a starting point for the JS test framework. You can visit
/qunit/ with DEBUG=True in your settings to access the JS
test runner.

Fixes bug 961509.

Change-Id: Ica33765660d0ed80f22c71bc96f122c3fc8b80cc
"}]
commit_message:
JavaScript Refactor.

Cleans up Horizon's JavaScript to make it properly modular and
well-organized.

Adds unit tests written in QUnit for some of the JS modules
as a starting point for the JS test framework. You can visit
/qunit/ with DEBUG=True in your settings to access the JS
test runner.

Fixes bug 961509.

Change-Id: Ica33765660d0ed80f22c71bc96f122c3fc8b80cc

Code looks good and works well. There is just one case that is missing - i.e. the fixed_ips can include either subnet and ip or just subnet (in this case an ip from the subnet is generated)

For example:

commit_message:
add --fixed-ip argument to create port

add --fixed-ip argument to create port and add list and dict type for unknow option
now we can use known option feature:
 quantumv2 create_port --fixed-ip subnet_id=<id>,ip_address=<ip>
--fixed-ip subnet_id=<id>, ip_address=<ip2> network_id
or unknown option feature:
one ip:
 quantumv2 create_port network_id --fixed_ips type=dict list=true subnet_id=<id>,ip_address=<ip>
two ips:
quantumv2 create_port network_id --fixed_ips type=dict subnet_id=<id>,ip_address=<ip> subnet_id=<id>,ip_address=<ip2>
to create port
Please download: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/8794/4 and
set core_plugin = quantum.db.db_base_plugin_v2.QuantumDbPluginV2 on quantum server side

Patch 2: support cliff 1.0
Patch 3: support specify auth strategy, for now, any other auth strategy than keystone will disable auth,
format port output
Patch 4: format None as '' when outputing, deal with list of dict, add QUANTUMCLIENT_DEBUG env to enable http req/resp print,
which is helpful for testing nova integration
Patch 5: fix interactive mode, and initialize_app problem

Change-Id: I693848c75055d1947862d55f4b538c1dfb1e86db

commit_message:
Remove direct access to glance client

All internal clients of Glance should be using GlanceImageService. This
refactors the code in the xen and vmware virt drivers that were
directly instantiating a glance.client object

Related to bp integrate-python-glanceclient

Change-Id: I354254060e400d9c1dfd6d041b071e3960a9ece6

commit_message:
Run devstack as stack instead of jenkins.

So that sudo permissions may be revoked after they aren't needed.
Fixes bug #1016567.

Change-Id: Ib8b287e8252397a168fbe23672b2822509511d59

commit_message:
Support last version of upcoming rootwrap changes

Hopefully last adjustment needed to support the upcoming rootwrap
changes at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/8747/. I think core
reviewers there finally agree on where things should live and how they
should be named.

'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-06-25 12:05:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Yong,

I actually think that Jason was intended that "device_id" represent the "instance_id".  He didn't want to use "instance_id", as in the future, services other than Nova may use Quantum, and "instance" seemed Nova-specific.  I'm fine with either name, but there's no need to have both fields.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-06-25 12:05:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

In this case, maybe we can use port id as virf uuid, which can be used by plugin and virf driver to generate tap device,
device_id is instance_id.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-06-25 12:05:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

we use device_id to store instance_id, use port id as virf id'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-25 12:05:46.000000000', 'message': 'add instance_id into port model
blueprint improved-nova-quantum-integration

we add an instance_id into port so that we can remove the use of the virtual interface table in nova.
In fact, since we have no integer id in network model, which is used in virtual interface table in nova,
we have to device another way to remember the relationships between port and instance. the instance_id in
port model is this design.

Change-Id: I927a56730e98b84183cb727365f6146986c6bb8d
'}]
commit_message:
add instance_id into port model
blueprint improved-nova-quantum-integration

we add an instance_id into port so that we can remove the use of the virtual interface table in nova.
In fact, since we have no integer id in network model, which is used in virtual interface table in nova,
we have to device another way to remember the relationships between port and instance. the instance_id in
port model is this design.

Change-Id: I927a56730e98b84183cb727365f6146986c6bb8d

subject: More robust mailmap parsing.
messages:
[{'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-06-25 02:20:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Awesome. If you're fixing this a better way, then I will leave it to you!"}, {'account_id': 2934, 'date': '2012-06-25 02:20:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

It might break existing parsers. The canonical_email and alias must contain only the email address, "<email@address.com>. This change makes it to include full name as well, "Full Name <email@address.com>".

If i'm right, the inconsistency between nova and novaclient is because, the latest changes to openstack-common/openstack/common/setup.py are not merged in nova. I've proposed a fix to merge it as per 8080.
  https://review.openstack.org/8080

The patch in 8080 is to fix inconsistent formatting in mailmap and also merge this library, openstack-common/openstack/common/setup.py, so the tests pass. Once it's merged, i'll fix nova to generate AUHTORS file, by honoring the specification in .mailmap file.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-06-25 02:20:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-25 02:20:47.000000000', 'message': "More robust mailmap parsing.

The project has two different versions of this floating around. The one in
nova just splits on space and doesn't work with python-novaclient .mailmap
which has full names in some of its entries. The one in python-novaclient
tries splitting with an if, but it breaks in nova. This one should properly
get the mapping built properly.

Change-Id: I32974957494728e4fcc1667e301026dcd7fb8004
"}]
commit_message:
More robust mailmap parsing.

The project has two different versions of this floating around. The one in
nova just splits on space and doesn't work with python-novaclient .mailmap
which has full names in some of its entries. The one in python-novaclient
tries splitting with an if, but it breaks in nova. This one should properly
get the mapping built properly.

Change-Id: I32974957494728e4fcc1667e301026dcd7fb8004

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-24 21:35:40.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for pre-release versioning.

This encapsulates all of the logic currently in the CI system
create-tarball.sh script into the actual sdist command. It also
generates a file in the project package containing the version so that
pkg-resources calls can be used to extract the version from installed
information.

Change-Id: I744f8564628b9a659b7eb1652b9d733df9f1d716
'}]
commit_message:
Add support for pre-release versioning.

This encapsulates all of the logic currently in the CI system
create-tarball.sh script into the actual sdist command. It also
generates a file in the project package containing the version so that
pkg-resources calls can be used to extract the version from installed
information.

Change-Id: I744f8564628b9a659b7eb1652b9d733df9f1d716

commit_message:
Corrections for stricter pep8 checking.

Updates the code to reflect stricter pep8 checking standards
for pep8 1.3+. Also adds a pep8 config file to silence
unnecessary indentation errors.

Removes the "reverse bugfix" monkeypatch since Django 1.4 is
now required.

Implements blueprint upgrade-pep8.

Change-Id: I7343321627d8ccd1598f39323821133168a645cc

commit_message:
Fix bug 911892

Adds Identity service definitions and image to Identity management chapter
of Compute Administration Manual.

Also changes "unknown" to "local" in the pom.xml file as I find that
more descriptive of what's happening when you locally build with mvn
without passing in -D parameters.

Patch set 2 makes PDF output of image more readable.

Change-Id: I34d1d6421bb59cd5be1df30b273abd5b07e3b19a

commit_message:
Return the correct ec2 access/secret when generating ec2rc.sh.

Fixes bug 1014185

Horizon was returning the 1st ec2 pair instead of the one
linked to the tenant for users in multiple tenants.

"}, {'account_id': 2230, 'date': '2012-06-12 19:42:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

That Jenkins failure looks like an anomaly. It didn't fail the other times it built it, and I have only changed the commit message between versions of this patch."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-13 17:26:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

The code you added seems out of place...we can't just implement this in the v1 api controller, what about v2? Additionally, why can't each specific store driver figure out the exact size of its images? Are any of our store drivers even block-based?"}, {'account_id': 2230, 'date': '2012-06-13 18:44:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> we can't just implement this in the v1 api controller, what about v2?

I can move it to v2 if you'd prefer. We're using it internally with v1 and hoped to push it upstream, especially given the lack of maturity of v2.

>Additionally, why can't each specific store driver figure out the exact size of its images?

Because it may not have access to that data without a lot of hacking. Not all block storage devices store the size of the data as written. I see no non-hacky way to discover the expected size within the store, given the very little data available there.

> Are any of our store drivers even block-based?

RBD is. It also happens to store the original size of the file, a property which is unusual among pure block storage devices."}, {'account_id': 2230, 'date': '2012-06-14 17:45:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

It's also worth pointing out that although this patch is applied in the api file, it's really a feature addition to allow new store backends, not a change in any existing API contract."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-14 21:39:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

So I agree with the idea of helping support block-based stores, but I want to make sure we put this logic in the right place. It definitely doesn't belong in the checked_iter in the v1 API - it has nothing to do with the v1 spec and needs to be available for the v2 API image data controller as well. How would you feel about providing a base ImageIterator class in glance.store.base that owns this logic?"}, {'account_id': 2230, 'date': '2012-06-14 23:01:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I agree, it's fairly out of place where it is right now.

That move makes sense. We'll add the checked_iter() functionality to the base class, and then we can wrap what the storage backends return, if they return an iterator which does not inherit from our ImageIterator."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-06-23 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-06-23 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Allow block backends.

This patch allows the definition of block-based backends which return
block aligned chunks, rather than exactly the number of bytes originally
written.

Implements bp block-aligned-backends

Change-Id: I9c85efb1a6caaf2be8d70fff97b3aa58d12f3f52

At the Folsom Design Summit, it was decided that infrastructure HA
(high availability of core OpenStack services and some external
services that OpenStack relies on, such as MySQL and RabbitMQ) should
be an overarching goal for Folsom. It was also agreed that a large
portion of that effort would be in documentation rather than
development, because OpenStack should make use of existing high-availability
solutions where available -- rather than reinvent the wheel.

This is the first step toward such a High Availability Guide,

commit_message:
Add High Availability Guide

At the Folsom Design Summit, it was decided that infrastructure HA
(high availability of core OpenStack services and some external
services that OpenStack relies on, such as MySQL and RabbitMQ) should
be an overarching goal for Folsom. It was also agreed that a large
portion of that effort would be in documentation rather than
development, because OpenStack should make use of existing high-availability
solutions where available -- rather than reinvent the wheel.

This is the first step toward such a High Availability Guide,
containing a root document, an introduction to HA, and a
pom.xml file to make everything build in Maven.

Change-Id: I405faf77042d97683a59aa757f00e7d6ea015b0d

commit_message:
Add ERROR_ON_CLONE.

This lets the user assert that stack.sh should never need to clone
any git repositories.  If set to True, and devstack does need to
clone a git repo, stack.sh will exit with an error.

This is useful in testing environments to make sure that the correct
code is being tested instead of silently falling back on cloning
from the public repos.

Change-Id: Ic0312ab4df492c5cf2e04c08aa7669a81736daa6

commit_message:
Change the label of devstack nodes on use.

Instead of disconnecting then node, change the label to
"devstack-used", which is a label we will never use for a job.
That way the node will not be re-used, but we don't get a warning
in the job console output about the node going offline.

Also, make sure the nodes are created for exclusive use
(tied jobs only).

Change-Id: Ib162d78baee17452cec13c150235f3584737d3c3

commit_message:
Ensure existing image properties are not deleted

Fixes LP #1014226

Passing the X-Glance-Registry-Purge-Props: false
header to the image_update Glance client method
prevents previously-set image properties from being
marked deleted.

Change-Id: I91e927f8c95205cae11bad0d93361f1c9951d62d

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-19 22:07:26.000000000', 'message': 'Login/Logout redirects with Django variables

The login/logout url patterns now use
the Django LOGIN_URL and LOGOUT_URL

The default redirect url after a successful login
now uses as default the Django LOGIN_REDIRECT_URL
with possible override using HORIZON_CONFIG.user_home
in settings file. There are 3 cases:

* no user_home in settings.HORIZON_CONFIG - uses
Django LOGIN_REDIRECT_URL
* user_home = None in settings.HORIZON_CONFIG -
will default to the primary dashboard(the current
fall-back behavior)
* user_home = 'something' - it will be used to
determine the actual redirect url

Fixes bug 980434

N.B. There is one edge case, if the user_home is set as "/"
this will cause a redirect loop, as "/" is mapped to 'splash'
view, which is a redirect view, and doesn't render html(if the user
is authenticated)... So the redirect url
should be always set to a real view that renders html.

Change-Id: I28e25566199393382639da9ca2022d1850f25a94
'}, {'created': '2012-06-22 14:11:53.000000000', 'message': "Login/Logout redirects with Django variables

The login/logout url patterns now use
the Django LOGIN_URL and LOGOUT_URL

The default redirect url after a successful login
now uses as default the Django LOGIN_REDIRECT_URL
with possible override using HORIZON_CONFIG.user_home
in settings file. There are 3 cases:

* no user_home in settings.HORIZON_CONFIG - uses
Django LOGIN_REDIRECT_URL
* user_home = None in settings.HORIZON_CONFIG -
will default to the primary dashboard(the current
fall-back behavior)
* user_home = 'something' - it will be used to
determine the actual redirect url

Fixes bug 980434

Patch Set 2:
Restored the previous behavior - splash page('/')
redirects to /nova or /syspanel, depending on the user,
while /home/ will redirect to the 'user_home' setting
(or LOGIN_REDIRECT_URL if user_home is not set).
The same logic will be applied after user logs in.

Change-Id: I28e25566199393382639da9ca2022d1850f25a94
"}]
commit_message:
Login/Logout redirects with Django variables

The login/logout url patterns now use
the Django LOGIN_URL and LOGOUT_URL

The default redirect url after a successful login
now uses as default the Django LOGIN_REDIRECT_URL
with possible override using HORIZON_CONFIG.user_home
in settings file. There are 3 cases:

* no user_home in settings.HORIZON_CONFIG - uses
Django LOGIN_REDIRECT_URL
* user_home = None in settings.HORIZON_CONFIG -
will default to the primary dashboard(the current
fall-back behavior)
* user_home = 'something' - it will be used to
determine the actual redirect url

Fixes bug 980434

Patch Set 2:
Restored the previous behavior - splash page('/')
redirects to /nova or /syspanel, depending on the user,
while /home/ will redirect to the 'user_home' setting
(or LOGIN_REDIRECT_URL if user_home is not set).
The same logic will be applied after user logs in.

Change-Id: I28e25566199393382639da9ca2022d1850f25a94

commit_message:
Use horizon's panel template loader.

Moves the panel templates into their respective panel's directories.
This tightens the grouping of logically-related elements and reduces
the need to duplicate the entire dashboard structure in the dashboard's
templates directory.

Implements blueprint use-template-loader.

Change-Id: I05ffb6a96f4909c1285beda7874ccfa96404547f

commit_message:
Fix bug 911892

Adds Identity service definitions and image to Identity management chapter
of Compute Administration Manual.

Also changes "unknown" to "local" in the pom.xml file as I find that
more descriptive of what's happening when you locally build with mvn
without passing in -D parameters.

Patch set 2 makes PDF output of image more readable.

Change-Id: I34d1d6421bb59cd5be1df30b273abd5b07e3b19a
