subject: Allow CPU model to be specified against glance images
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-14 12:39:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/3010/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/4412/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/614/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/622/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/5167/ : FAILURE
"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-18 11:54:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

My first reaction here is that this seems really weird

Why would a cloud provider their users to specify cpu models directly when uploading images?

Could you elaborate on the use case you see a bit more? Is this something for the cloud admin or cloud users?"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-06-18 12:31:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Why would a cloud provider their users to specify cpu models directly when uploading images?

> Could you elaborate on the use case you see a bit more? Is this something for the cloud admin or cloud users?

To be honest, I'm not 100% sure myself whether something like this is useful enough.

I can see in case of a general purpose public cloud, the provider may well explicitly /not/ want this feature, since it could well restrict what nodes an image can be scheduled on, which may be bad for the provider's hardware utilization overall. This in fact suggests, this patch ought to have a switch to explicitly disable the use of per-image CPU models

The area I imagined value is in the case of private clouds in a HPC environment, where it is important to squeeze every last drop of performance out of VMs. In such a case, the host admin probably wants to be fairly conservative in configuring the default host CPU model, to maximise flexibility in deploying common VMs, at the cost of more limited peak performance. They may still wish to allow their users to deploy certain HPC apps with very tailored CPU models though to maximise performance. So if we didn't have this per-image CPU model config, those HPC users might be forced to have to use a traditional datacenter mgmt app like RHEV-M/oVirt, instead of taking advantage of OpenStack cloud.


One thing I now realize is missing to this patch, is a change to the Nova schedular to actually check CPU model compatibility when scheduling VMs. AFAICT, currently such compat checks are only done on migration, not initial deployment."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-18 13:03:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The HPC case you describe doesn't really sound like an ideal use case for OpenStack. As you say, it sounds more like a datacenter virt thing

I guess we could live with the feature if it was eenabled with a config option that defaulted to off. However, it really feels like something we're just adding because it's easy to implement.

Another thing I don't like about this is the way it leaks libvirt specific properties out into the self-service API. A better way to implement this would be to allow the cpu model to be specified in the instance type and have some way for an image to require a certain instance type"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-06-18 13:05:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Ok, unless someone else comments strongly asking for this kind of capability lets just drop this patch for now. It can always be revisited later if desired.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-06-19 14:46:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Based on discussion, setting CPU models against images is not desirable. Instead they should be set against instance types.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-14 12:19:08.000000000', 'message': "Allow CPU model to be specified against glance images

To allow individual disk images registered with glance to
override the default host CPU model, add support for two
properties 'libvirt_cpu_mode', and 'libvirt_cpu_model'
which have the same semantics as the global Nova config
options with the same names

eg to request the host CPU:

 # glance add container_format=ovf \
      libvirt_cpu_mode=host-passthrough \
      name=f16-more is_public=true \
      disk_format=qcow2 < /path/to/disk

Or a custom CPU model:

 # glance add container_format=ovf \
      libvirt_cpu_mode=custom \
      libvirt_cpu_model=core2duo \
      name=f16-more is_public=true \
      disk_format=qcow2 < /path/to/disk

Fixes: bug #1003373
Implements: blueprint libvirt-xml-cpu-model
Change-Id: Ib1aa09caf748923c85d6ee3548faa329e1e30f2c
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Allow CPU model to be specified against glance images

To allow individual disk images registered with glance to
override the default host CPU model, add support for two
properties 'libvirt_cpu_mode', and 'libvirt_cpu_model'
which have the same semantics as the global Nova config
options with the same names

eg to request the host CPU:

 # glance add container_format=ovf \
      libvirt_cpu_mode=host-passthrough \
      name=f16-more is_public=true \
      disk_format=qcow2 < /path/to/disk

Or a custom CPU model:

 # glance add container_format=ovf \
      libvirt_cpu_mode=custom \
      libvirt_cpu_model=core2duo \
      name=f16-more is_public=true \
      disk_format=qcow2 < /path/to/disk

Fixes: bug #1003373
Implements: blueprint libvirt-xml-cpu-model
Change-Id: Ib1aa09caf748923c85d6ee3548faa329e1e30f2c
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

subject: blueprint Local File System Class to Support Extended Capabilities
messages:
[{'account_id': 2401, 'date': '2012-05-04 01:12:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-05-04 02:08:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

It seems like this could be implemented with much less risk almost entirely in middleware. zfs middleware would set env['swift.setup_partition'], setup_tmpdir, and setup_objdir, which would be passed along to the Controllers which would use them if set. The middleware could also intercept the STATUS method to handle that.

Those that choose not to use it would only have their systems doing a few extra env checks for values that don't exist."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-05-04 18:40:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

In addition to all of gholt's comments, with which I agree entirely, there's one particularly noteworthy line of code in here, in swift/common/lfs/zfs.py:24: "import nspyzfs".

nspyzfs isn't included in this change, nor is it on PyPi, nor is it anywhere else I can find. Google only finds that string once, in a mailing list message (https://lists.launchpad.net/openstack/msg07223.html) where someone else is asking about nspyzfs.

One of two things has to happen: either nspyzfs must be made available (e.g. by inclusion in this change), or the dependency on it must be removed. Until that happens, this change cannot be merged into Swift.'}, {'account_id': 1330, 'date': '2012-05-04 19:41:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I discussed these points with Victor. We agree that we should avoid explicitly importing nspyzfs. We will redo the code to use a dynamic import, and clearly state the naming convention for the library that an enhanced local file system is supposed to provide.

Such libraries are inherently platform-specific code. Does the Openstack project want to host these? Or is merely stating the dependency and the interface clear enough. NexentaStor is an open source solution, so publishing this library is not in conflict with our business model. However other file system vendors have proprietary file systems and may be unable to provide open source libraries to facilitate access to their file systems. It is not Nexenta's intent to exclude other vendors from being able to unlock their equivalent features."}, {'account_id': 1330, 'date': '2012-05-04 19:44:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

A middleware solution will not work.

To clarify the rationale for this Victor will be adding the patches to the ring-builder to this patchset. There was no strict coding dependency, so he had been planning that a later patchset. However there is a logical dependency, in that the entire rationale for changing swift code is to allow the swift layer to rely on enhanced data protection from the local file system when it is available. 

I do not see how you can do that in middleware, the actual ring has to be constructed differently.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-05-04 23:01:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Perhaps I'd need to see all the code to get the whole picture, but I'm not sure I understand why a ring builder change in another patch set would preclude this patch set from being implemented as middleware.

I'll wait for the other patch set and re-review then."}, {'account_id': 2401, 'date': '2012-05-07 21:50:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

It's not problem to remove zfs.py I add this module just as example. Most Swift users will not have any effect of this patch (if fs is not defined in config file or fs=xfs). But there are some users who run swift on ZFS or another filesystem. So this type of users can easily extend swift functionality by feature that provide their file system. For example in ZFS you can create new filesystem for each partition of object, or you can add functionality for self-healing mirrored replication. Only with adding new module to package swift.common.lfs."}, {'account_id': 2401, 'date': '2012-05-08 00:41:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-05-08 01:23:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'll still don't see why this can't be implemented mostly outside of the Swift repo. I see where hooks are needed in the account, container, and object servers and I see where hooks are needed in the ring builder to balance based on possible mirroring. But perhaps I've haven't explained well enough what I mean by hooks and rest, so here's a quick sample:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/16074/

Obviously that code is incomplete, I've only shown the account server modified with the hooks for example. But the principle can easy be applied to all three servers.

In this way, those who do not choose to use the LFS model at all won't have the middleware installed and therefore the hook calls will be skipped. There would be a very minimal slowdown in checking for the hooks as compared to the current proposal. And there would be much less risk."}, {'account_id': 2401, 'date': '2012-05-08 01:48:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Sorry, that still don't implement LFS in middleware, I know what mean hooking. I worked today on changes for ring builder.
How I can implement hooks in ring builder?"}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-05-08 01:58:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

True, my example does not implement everything; it was just an example to show what I meant. The middleware approach would provide the exact same functionality with much less change to the core Swift repo, unless you have a specific example it would not work for?

As far as the ring, I think what you have now looks reasonable; I'd need time to review it carefully but the approach seems fine so far."}, {'account_id': 1330, 'date': '2012-05-08 21:38:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Responding to gholt's comments.

We're moving as much out of the core code as possible based on your suggestions - but some modifications to the core logic cannot be avoided. Instead they are carefully done so as to have no impact when no local file system library is in use (that is, XFS/Linux users will see no impact at all).

The first area where the core must change is the ring builder. From your comments I believe you understand the rationale here. Doing self-healing mirroring (not just mirroring) in the local file system would be largely pointless unless it resulted in there being *less* network replication. It would be akin to taking out a *second* health insurance policy for your data's health without at least reducing the level of coverage from your prior health care provider.

The second area is dealing with a partition replica being in a *degraded* state. That is, only one mirror is up and running. Without the LFS patch, a partition replica only has two different states: up or down. With LFS it can be up, down or degraded.

This has implications where a consensus has to be reached before this code can be truly merged into a release.

For example, automatic replication is clearly impacted. While replicating a degraded partition is still the probable response, the replication can take place *from* the degraded copy. When a partition replica is only up or down the replication must take place from a *different* replica.

It is also conceivable that some sites would not want to do this, but would prefer to dispatch a replacement drive to the impacted server so that that Object Server could repair itself. Most data centers prefer to avoid dispatching technicians as soon as drives go bad, so this is an unlikely policy, but it might make sense to poll potential operators to see if they would like an option like this in the replication daemon.

Additionally, the LFS patch can invoke replication methods in the LFS library that are specific to the local file system and more efficient than generic rsync replication. With ZFS this is the zfs send/recv operations. However having some form of optimized replication is a capability that you will find in many file systems, not just ZFS.

At least to our understanding of how middleware works in Swift, it is not applicable to the operation of background daemons such as replication.

The second area is simply in displaying this third status in the various reports and dashboards that support Swift. I assume users would want the most accurate information available to be displayed, but right now that code expects only two different values."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-05-08 22:22:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Ah cool, thanks guys. Along these lines, you might want to have a look at Sam's pending ring changes at:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/6845/

As these are almost certainly going to cause merge conflicts at the least, and probably algorithm changes too. We've been working through that one since the 26th and I think it's close to approval."}, {'account_id': 2401, 'date': '2012-05-08 22:40:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2401, 'date': '2012-05-16 23:07:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned'}, {'account_id': 2401, 'date': '2012-06-19 14:42:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Restored'}, {'account_id': 2401, 'date': '2012-06-19 14:44:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
blueprint Local File System Class to Support Extended Capabilities

A new class is proposed that would allow a Data Server to define
optional enhanced capabilities that the Swift Object Server would
be able to use. The first example is to allow a platform to indicate
that its Local File System has been configured with self-healing
mirrored replication, allowing Swift to configure fewer network replicas.

Add mirror_copies support to RingBuilder.

Add lfs middleware.

Change-Id: If26dddd90f35acbc65d59646e81caa38fbb56d4a

bump to prevent expiry'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-06-08 15:26:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Bump'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-06-08 15:32:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Do we really need to infinitely "bump" drafts?

Also, doesn't Gerrit have a draft facility or something?'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-06-08 15:35:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

yeah there is but there is no way to have a normal review go to draft (only draft=>normal review).

Victor you probably want to fix your commit message and reference to the proper blueprint, i.e:

Large file upload in single upload support

- Implement blueprint large-file-upload.
- This a draft patch to support uploading large object to swift If the object is larger than 5G it splited into segments and then created a manifest object.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-06-08 15:41:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

no we don't want to infinitely bump stuff, but we should provide a definite up or down.

I'm interested in this patch, but I haven't taken the time to review it. We've discussed how this could work, so I'd like to see how much it works with those ides."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-06-08 15:54:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Ah okay, got it. I wasn't even considering reviewing just because it was "draft" so I figured he was just still working on it.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-06-11 23:36:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I vote -1 but obviously others can override that.

I don't like this feature because it allows the user to make a request that is highly prone to failure (network timeouts, disk timeouts, etc.) Large object uploads, in my opinion, should always be done in segments where the user is aware of what they are asking.

Aside from that, this is labelled as 'draft' and shouldn't be committed as such. And there are no tests (this one should get both unit and functional tests) and zero documentation.

Due to the patchset's age, it also has a merge conflict."}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-06-12 12:38:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I agree with Greg this may be causing more problems than benefits. 

Maybe something like that can be done as a middleware to offer users this option for a specific usage of swift where this would be relevant (i.e: local lan upload).'}, {'account_id': 2401, 'date': '2012-06-19 14:43:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
blueprint Large Single Uploads
This a draft patch for support swift large object upload. If object
content length > 5G it splited into segments and then created a
manifest object.

Change-Id: Icdb1bb5b322801572cff4b7c7c2cbb13a0b44ccf

[{'created': '2012-06-13 19:20:19.000000000', 'message': "Run glance-manage db_sync.

Updates stack.sh so that it runs glance-manage db_sync. This
should pave the way for us to default Glance DB auto-creation
to False in Glance.

Previously we would rely on glance-registry (and glance-api in Folsom)
to auto create the DB for us. I've found this to be a bit racey
so explicitly using glance-manage seems the way to go.

Change-Id: I61f165db6e0591e819d12aa2e2a4d336ad1172c3
"}]
commit_message:
Run glance-manage db_sync.

Updates stack.sh so that it runs glance-manage db_sync. This
should pave the way for us to default Glance DB auto-creation
to False in Glance.

Previously we would rely on glance-registry (and glance-api in Folsom)
to auto create the DB for us. I've found this to be a bit racey
so explicitly using glance-manage seems the way to go.

Change-Id: I61f165db6e0591e819d12aa2e2a4d336ad1172c3

commit_message:
Support upcoming rootwrap.d config files

Add support in devstack for upcoming /etc/nova/rootwrap.d
configuration files. Note that we don't change anything if Nova
doesn't ship them, so devstack supports both cases.

This is the first step for blueprint folsom-nova-rootwrap. It needs
to go in first so that tests pass when rootwrap.d changes will be
proposed in Nova.

Change-Id: I0189575ed9adb1be61c8563ce8f3199c52fc08ff

Using epel rpm and leave it disabled after use

Change-Id: If6673e59afc545e51df3625d8259ec3fca9aaefb

should be generated automatically, based on git commits.

commit_message:
Generate AUTHORS file for swift.

Bug: 976267

Now that git commits are gated by CLA, we shouldn't enforce
committers to add an entry in AUTHORS file. The AUTHORS file
should be generated automatically, based on git commits.

* .gitignore
  Add AUTHORS file.

* .mailmap
  Fix mailmap entries to generate unique entries.

* AUTHORS
  Delete this file.

* AUTHORS.in
  Include original authors.

* setup.py
  Use command class to generate authors file.

* openstack-common.conf
  Configuration file to update openstack-common library.

* swift/openstack/__init__.py
* swift/openstack/common/__init__.py
* swift/openstack/common/setup.py
  Add setup.py from openstack-common.

Change-Id: If3b11b60a4dcb8b02bf08e42b7bf76731c7ddf76

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-11 14:41:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm willing to bet the NotAuthorized exception handling was added for a reason...maybe the db layer raises it if you try to get security groups for an instance you don't have access to? Let's leave it, but handle it in the same block as the InstanceNotFound."}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-06-11 15:15:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I think this should be confirmed by someone from the API standards group to see what the spec says should happen. But I agree, HTTPUnauthorized seems like the correct response. It's what I would prefer to see as a caller."}, {'account_id': 4126, 'date': '2012-06-11 15:23:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

That's probably why NotAuthorized was caught here indeed, but the logic in wsgi.ResourceHandlerException already handles it I believe. Is there any reason to prefer using different logic and http code for this one case? If so, I'll add a test, as removing the block did not cause the suite to fail."}, {'account_id': 4126, 'date': '2012-06-14 14:46:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Have looked at the use of NotAuthorized in a bit more depth.

From db/sqlalchemy/api.py the places that raise NotAuthorized are the helpers for validating a context, such as require_context which most functions use as a decorator. None of these checks are specific to security groups.

For the case of trying to get the security groups of a server you don't have access, the initial compute_api.get will always raise InstanceNotFound if the server has a different project_id to the context. This is the same behaviour as any other method involving servers.

The only places in the openstack api code that specifically translate NotAuthorized are the contrib/ modules, which probably just need updating."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-06-14 17:04:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It's not clear how you want to move forward with this patch. What are you thinking?"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-06-14 18:18:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

As far as I can tell the NotAuthorized and APIError are just out of date, so this fix looks correct.'}, {'account_id': 4126, 'date': '2012-06-15 10:51:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Brian, so, I think this branch is suitable for landing as-is, unless you've got any further issues with it?"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-18 15:15:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Looks good to me, and Martin's rationale for not needing to handle NotAuthorized makes sense ...

It looks to me like it shouldn't be possible to hit the NotAuthorized in require_context unless there's a bug or configuration error ... and even if it is raised, ResourceExceptionHandler will convert it unto a HTTPForbidden

Inline, I've pointed out a small thing worth fixing while we're clarifying the exception handling here"}, {'account_id': 4126, 'date': '2012-06-18 17:09:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-18 17:25:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
Handle missing server when getting security groups

Fix bug 1010486.

Treat InstanceNotFound as a 404 when querying the security groups of server
that does not exist. Also removes old exception translation, ApiError no
longer exists and NotAuthorized shouldn't need handling at this level.
Includes tweak suggested by Mark McLoughlin in review.

Change-Id: Iaeada84dbadc232968f792c6f4855bf61cc5a5ae

Hi,
I have a number of comments:
1. When you commit a patch please make sure that the first line of the commit description has a short summary of what you are doing (this is via git commit -a --amend). "Upload patch set 2" is a bit cryptic. Plesae note that gerrit maintains a history of all of the comments so you do not need to update this with each change.
2. I suggest that you take a look at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/8513/ this removes a a number of unused functions.

commit_message:
removed "runthis" and other unused functions from utils.py

Fixes Bug #1012234

Removed all unused functions and imports from common/utils.py.

Patch set 2: Submitted same code by mistake
Patch set 3: removed commented code but inappropriate commit msg.
Patch set 4: removed commented code with appropriate commit msg. Removed pep8 changes for ucs plugin.

Change-Id: I0ec33be127ef0389685a378c6f8d39ce5cbdb58c

Eh.  Alphabetization is itself artificial: why should "A" come before "B"?  The answer is because someone came up with a rule that says, "A comes before B."  In the same way, someone came up with a rule that says "'from nova.network import api' alphabetizes as if it read 'import nova.network.api'".  I happen to neither agree nor disagree with that rule, but it is a rule, and doesn't take much to actually comply with, so…'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-19 01:38:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: No score

commit_message:
moved update cache functionality to the network api

previously the network manager get_instance_nw_info
was responsible for updating the cache. This is to
prevent calling that function in a confusing way.

part 2 of this patch was fixing bug997763
floating_ip_associate was removed from the compute
api. network api associate is now called directly.
network api floating_ip functions now require
instance as an argument in order to update cache.

Change-Id: Ie8daa017b99e48769afbac4862696ef0a8eb1067

commit_message:
Newer nose deprecated addSkip.

Instead of calling addSkip, the "right" thing to do now is
to inspect the error class and take action based on that.

Change-Id: Ie8e6075c4737c49b5094b65af84b443df523213e

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-18 17:09:22.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid thread creation prior to service launch.

It appears that the thread serving out the fake HTTP endpoint used
in the copy-from tests is causing intermittent hangs in the launched
glance service processes. These hangs manifest as calls to futex(2)
that never return, and occur almost daily in Smokestack.

The background to the thread/fork mismatch is explained in this
blog post:

 http://rachelbythebay.com/w/2011/06/07/forked

We avoid the issue by delaying the thread creation until after the
service processes have been launched by the testcase.

Change-Id: I68c6f1735e5001641994ed4f84ad879397ba8713
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid thread creation prior to service launch.

It appears that the thread serving out the fake HTTP endpoint used
in the copy-from tests is causing intermittent hangs in the launched
glance service processes. These hangs manifest as calls to futex(2)
that never return, and occur almost daily in Smokestack.

The background to the thread/fork mismatch is explained in this
blog post:

 http://rachelbythebay.com/w/2011/06/07/forked

We avoid the issue by delaying the thread creation until after the
service processes have been launched by the testcase.

Change-Id: I68c6f1735e5001641994ed4f84ad879397ba8713

commit_message:
SM volume driver: DB changes and tests

Fixes the storage manager db api code in minor ways
like checking for duplicates during creation.
Adds tests for the storage manager db api.

Change-Id: I00f431ed9137b140f46b4e30cb953792d7307d22

commit_message:
Calling Super method from QuantumPortAwareScheduler.__init__

the quantum.plugins.cisco.nova.quantum_port_aware_scheduler.QuantumPortAwareScheduler class wasn't calling its superclass __init__.
the host_manager attribute of driver.Scheduler class wasn't initialized, and the scheduler was crashing when it was receiving a host message via amqp.

Fixes bug 994652

Change-Id: I733d80df8f87ff314f4233b10fa8afaf454eedf0

commit_message:
Add authZ through incorporation of policy checks.

Adds the policy openstack-common module and implements policy checks
for the v2 API.  Note that this cut only addresses whole objects (i.e.,
a subnet or a network or a port), not specific fields within objects.
(This means that attributes are not filtered out based on policies.)
Implements blueprint authorization-support-for-quantum.

Change-Id: I1b52b1791a1f14f0af6508a63a40a38e440f15fe

subject: add import_object_ns function
messages:
[{'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-06-18 21:48:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Gunicorn uses entry points to define its app and worker classes here is their function https://github.com/benoitc/gunicorn/blob/master/gunicorn/util.py#L106 (MIT Licensed.)'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-06-18 21:48:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Re, the time frame, I would rather it be in the os-common release for use in G, than be developed in G. I'm hoping that at the end of folsom we'll promote enough of the api's to stable to make a release."}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-06-18 21:48:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I'd rather we use entry_points and then have an OS-common function to get the specified entry that has published the entry point in the desired namespace, ie:

   entry_points = """
   [nova.virt.drivers]
   libvirt = nova.virt.libvirt:LibvirtDriver
    """'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-18 21:48:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I like this, it seems like a sensible, small, incremental addition.

I'm not sure how relevant entry points are here, given that the drivers being loaded are mostly expected to be in-tree, but it's something we can add later if it makes sense."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-06-18 21:48:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

We discussed the change offline and agreed that this is good for Folsom and we can look at entry points for G.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-06-18 21:48:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This feels like a re-invention of pkg_resources from setuptools.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-06-18 21:48:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This is an RFC review, I am happy for alternative directions / approaches.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-06-18 21:48:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Do you have a good reference for using entry points in this way? Most of what I'm find seems very focused on more of a hooks kind of use, and I'm trying to wrap my brain around how that would work with our largely singleton driver model in nova.

I also wonder if an entry point conversation might be best as a G design summit item, as it seems like there are other implications there, and it's pretty late in Folsom."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-06-18 21:48:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Do you have an example of what this would look like with pkg_resources in an openstack driver context? I'd be really interested to see what an alternate approach looks like in code so we could evaluate the two. Especially if it came from someone that was a bit more familiar with the pkg_resources / entrypoint model here than I am."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-18 21:48:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-openstack-common-merge/100/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-18 21:48:23.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-18 21:48:23.000000000', 'message': 'add import_object_ns function

To support bp:virt-driver-cleanup, there is a desire to have shorter
driver strings (i.e. libvirt.LibvirtDriver instead of
nova.virt.libvirt.LibvirtDriver). One way to support this is with
a new import_object variant that takes a namespace to load from.

If the code fails to load the driver in the prefered namespace it
will also try loading the full driver path, before throwing an
exception.

Change-Id: Ib97c92f38685ca89f29890f8015fc413acc744f8
'}]
commit_message:
add import_object_ns function

To support bp:virt-driver-cleanup, there is a desire to have shorter
driver strings (i.e. libvirt.LibvirtDriver instead of
nova.virt.libvirt.LibvirtDriver). One way to support this is with
a new import_object variant that takes a namespace to load from.

If the code fails to load the driver in the prefered namespace it
will also try loading the full driver path, before throwing an
exception.

Change-Id: Ib97c92f38685ca89f29890f8015fc413acc744f8

Stop revealing sensitive store info

Use simpler error messages and log the details.

Fixes bug: 1012268

commit_message:
Fix pep8 issues.

Fix a pep8 issue and pin the pep8 test to pep8 version 1.1. This
should prevent future changes from being unmergable by the pep8
gate after a pep8 upgrade.

Change-Id: Ic651c20ffd181fbd84ee360dcf4ad04625dde0fc

commit_message:
xensm: Fix xensm volume driver after uuid changes

Fixes Bug 1013436
Minor fixes after uuid in volumes were changed from
integers.
The parameters passed to create_vdi have changed, so
modify the call from SM code accordingly

Change-Id: I3d61f0221b23bba9a9e218209d5293be8960e2e2

commit_message:
Enforce an instance uuid for instance_test_and_set.

This method only has one caller (compute/api.py) and it turns out
was already always getting a uuid, so this is a relatively minor
change.

Change-Id: I5beae5a707be053903f40cc98ed43b66eaf945a9

commit_message:
added deprecated.warn helper method

provide a convenience method for indicating in code that a config
option the operateor will have to deal with exists in their environment.

Change-Id: I17b0c120d54b1db75c6bb29d107e4a15a5202e76

commit_message:
Replaces functions in utils.py with openstack/common/timeutils.py

Fixes bug #1008628

1. Edit openstack-common.conf and import nova/openstack/common/timeutils.py
2. Move time related functions from utils.py to timeutils.py
3. Replace following functions in utils.py with timeutils.py
- isotime
- parse_isotime
- strtime
- parse_strtime
- normalize_time
- is_older_than
- utcnow_ts
- utcnow
- set_time_override
- advance_time_delta
- advance_time_seconds
- clear_time_override
4. Remove datetime related functions and datetime related unittests

Change-Id: I9a92be286fb071b6237dd39495d88dae106e2ce0

commit_message:
option to bypass managment endpoint and timings support

--timings = show timings for each call made to nova (including auth)
--bypass_url = api node endpoint to use instead of one from service catalog

For example:
nova --timings --bypass_url=http://10.24.31.37:8774/v1.1/nova-staging boot --image f304d266-0a49-4877-b34c-63aea8360297 --flavor 3 delete_me_2

Change-Id: Ib2a258b7e969ad56ce4ee2bd64c61310278cb856

No real coding complaints, but I'm not really sure why we couldn't superimpose cpu_arch on the existing cpu_info dictionary?"}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2012-06-11 19:10:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

sandy,

I explained this in the previous commit.

chuck'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-06-12 00:52:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Chuck I asked the same thing as Sandy but missed the explanation too. Could you give a v quick explanation as to why cpu_info is not used. thanks.'}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2012-06-12 01:40:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Sorry I thought I did..

The reason why we have a seperate column for cpu_info in the cmopute_nodes table, is that libvirt might have not caught up with the architecture we want to support. An example of this was ARM. In the oneiric cycle, ARM was not recognized by libvirt because libvirt used dmidecode to determine what kind of CPU that libvirt is using on the host. This has been fixed going forward, however getting the real information from the host (ie: os.uname()[4]) is the best way to get this informatio and not from libvirt. So thats why cpu_info was not used.

To make it more clear I could rename the column compute_cpu_info?

chuck'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-06-12 08:21:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Thanks Chuck. I've seen gerrit drop comments, so thanks for redoing. I'd suggest a shorter comment along those lines would be appropriate at the "cpu arch" extraction point.

Though I'm now wondering, if this is just working around a libvirt bug, then perhaps we should just ensure that cpu_info['arch'] is correct. I.E. switch to using uname if we detect an erroneous value in arch_nodes[0].text or bad libvirt version. That might allow more sophisticated mappings of supported arches within libvirt in future?'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-06-12 12:33:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

My point exactly. 

I would drop cpu_arch and add a new key under cpu_info that has the trusted cpu info from uname. That way we don't have redundant fields, new columns and a db migration to add.

The cpu_info dict normalization needs to be validated anyway since xen and libvirt return slightly different structures anyway.

$0.02"}, {'account_id': 1313, 'date': '2012-06-12 15:29:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

totally agree with Sandy Walsh,we can add this to cpu_info."}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2012-06-12 18:45:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

I think the idea that Chuck has not been successful in conveying is that "cpu architecture of compute node" and "supported guest instance architectures" are different things.

Consider these scenarios:
 * Compute node_cpu_arch = 'x86_64', instance_arch = 'i386'.  This is generally accepted and per commit message, Chuck's patch handles this common case and defaults to allowing it.
 * Compute node_cpu_arch = 'x86_64', instance_arch = 'i386'.  The same situation as above, the provider wishes to contain the execution of i386 instances.  Perhaps they have N nodes, but only want to allow "legacy i386" instances on M of them.  To account for this, the 'cpu_arch' field would contain only 'x86_64'.
 * Compute node_cpu_arch = 'x86_64', instance_arch = 'arm'.  Normal path would b e to deny this, but it is possible that in a development environment this would be desireable.  If I install qemu-system-arm onto my compute nodes, I may explicitly want this behavior.

The point is, that compute node cpu arch is a separate thing from "instance architectures allowed to run on this compute node".'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-06-12 19:03:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

That's an important distinction, but is that what's intended? This is the uname of the host, not the guest. If we want to limit the *possible* guest cpu architectures, shouldn't that be done with host capabilities and the instance type "extra attributes"?'}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2012-06-12 19:12:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Sandy,

yes thats the original intention of this merge request.'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-06-12 19:24:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

I see, well then:

1. I don't see how this would do it (since it's the cpu architecture of the host, not the guest)

2. host capabilities might be a better approach to defining which accepted cpu architectures are supported on a given host. These get sent to the HostManager by each Compute node. 

The ComputeFilter already does this. https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/scheduler/filters/compute_filter.py

Unless I'm still missing something? 

Sorry for making this more complex than it needs to be :/"}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-06-13 15:09:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Just cross referencing https://review.openstack.org/#/c/8089/ which seems to offer similar capabilities through configuration'}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2012-06-14 00:24:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Rebased'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-14 00:31:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Doesn't seem to work

This is a lighter/simpler version of the previous edition.

This version will check the guest architecture that an individual compute node to build an list of available architectures to run on a compute node. The information is stored in the permitted_instance_types and stuffed into the cpu_info dict for a given host.

When the filter is activate for a given nova scheduler, it will check the host capabilities of a given host and compare the instance to be run against the permitted_instance_types the host, it will filter out the host if the instance cannot run on a host via the permitted_instance_types.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-14 02:43:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2012-06-14 19:51:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

This looks good to me.  There are a few things that I'd like to see addressed in future enhancements:

a.) I don't like the string 'permitted_instance_types', as it contains "instance_type", which is confusing as it actually has nothing to do with instance_type, but rather with instance_arch.

b.) I'd like to see 'permitted_instance_types' (renamed) settable via a nova-compute flag.  This would allow the administrator to have a set of x86_64 systems that they only allowed x86_64 instances to run on.  Or, allow them to override the auto detection for whatever reason.

c.) I wonder if it might make more sense to have the translation of arch (i686 -> i386) done on the compute node.  Ie, the nova-compute node would explicitly state that it could run 'i386', 'i586', 'i686' arches rather.
This isn't so important for x86 arch, but possibly more relevant for other "sub arches" (ie, arm, powerpc...).  Basically, the node has more data available to set this correctly.

I'd almost recommend the string change in 'a' now.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-06-14 19:59:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-07 02:48:50.000000000', 'message': 'Add CPU arch filter scheduler support

In a mixed environment of running different CPU architecutres,
one would not want to run an ARM instance on a X86_64 host and
vice versa.

This scheduler filter option with prevent instances running
on a host that it is not intended for.

The ArchFilter is not turned on by default.

Change-Id: I17bd103f00c25d6006a421252c9c8dcfd2d2c49b
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
'}, {'created': '2012-06-07 02:50:28.000000000', 'message': 'Add CPU arch filter scheduler support

In a mixed environment of running different CPU architecutres,
one would not want to run an ARM instance on a X86_64 host and
vice versa.

This scheduler filter option with prevent instances running
on a host that it is not intended for.

This scheulder filter takes in account that you can run an i386
instance on an x86_64 compute node.

Also adds ARM as a valid arch to the filter.

The ArchFilter is not turned on by default.

commit_message:
Add CPU arch filter scheduler support

In a mixed environment of running different CPU architecutres,
one would not want to run an ARM instance on a X86_64 host and
vice versa.

This scheduler filter option will prevent instances running
on a host that it is not intended for.

The libvirt driver queries the guest capabilities of the
host and stores the guest arches in the permitted_instances_types
list in the cpu_info dict of the host.

The Xen equivalent will be done later in another commit.

The arch filter will compare the instance arch against
the permitted_instances_types of a host
and filter out invalid hosts.

Also adds ARM as a valid arch to the filter.

The ArchFilter is not turned on by default.

Change-Id: I17bd103f00c25d6006a421252c9c8dcfd2d2c49b
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

1) Set the default based on wherever this code has been copied to.

2) If we fail to import the backend, replace 'nova.rpc' with
'nova.openstack.common.rpc' just in case the value came from an older
nova configuration file.  Backwards compatibility is a good thing.

Change-Id: I9ad7c084a2f0813ca1559115e7612f0a24fcce67
"}]
commit_message:
rpc: Update rpc_backend handling.

Part of blueprint common-rpc.

This patch updates the rpc_backend option handling in a couple of ways.

1) Set the default based on wherever this code has been copied to.

2) If we fail to import the backend, replace 'nova.rpc' with
'nova.openstack.common.rpc' just in case the value came from an older
nova configuration file.  Backwards compatibility is a good thing.

Change-Id: I9ad7c084a2f0813ca1559115e7612f0a24fcce67

subject: Add gettext support.
messages:
[{'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-18 15:21:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hmm, I don't think this is the right thing

gettext.install('openstack-common') will set the global domain to 'openstack-common' so that when you do _('foo') it looks for the translation of 'foo' in openstack-common's message catalog - this would break translations in the projects using the library

What we really want the rpc code to do is gettext.dgettext('openstack-common', 'foo') so that it looks up messages in openstack-common's message catalog without affecting the projects which use it"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-06-18 15:21:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Thanks, Mark.  That makes sense.  I'll make those changes."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-06-18 15:21:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Restored

I'm going to upload a new rev.  How about something like this?"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-06-18 15:21:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Note that I know very little about gettext.  I don't know that this is something we want to do in openstack-common or not.  I can just as easily strip out the _() usage from the rpc code if there's a reason not to use it here ..."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-06-18 15:21:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-18 15:21:00.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-18 15:21:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-openstack-common-merge/81/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-06-18 15:21:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I know nothing of the world of gettext, but from what I can tell from the python docs, this is Bueno.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-18 15:21:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Yeah, looks good to me too

Only concern I have is that this shouldn't be a public API, but we can worry about that when actually make openstack-common a library"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-06-18 15:21:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-06-18 15:21:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}]

commit_message:
Add gettext support.

This patch adds gettext support for openstack-common modules.  In the
process of pulling in the rpc code, I didn't want to remove the usage of
_() that was already in there.  This allows it to stay in a way that
doesn't conflict with gettext usage in the project using
openstack-common.

Change-Id: I9cad006f81244f0cce7b7f28659fa1daa5a4268a

commit_message:
Added vlan range management for OVS plugin

* Added integer config flags: vlan_min, vlan_max
* If vlan_min is larger than vlan_max log warn and use default values
* Changed test_vlan_map.py in favor removed definitions of VlanMap class

Change-Id: Iaba819e62d70a9c9935cae195718dbf74d13884a

This looks fine to me - Sean's counter-point to Doug's suggestion makes sense"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-18 13:20:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Approved

y u no mrg?'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-06-18 13:20:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-06-18 13:20:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-06-18 13:20:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

The question I have is that if we actually import the object through the normal methods, have we polluted our namespace so that we can't trust the results of the OpenStack importer any more?"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-06-18 13:20:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

The import statement and __import__ function should be calling the same logic to resolve the desired name to a package or module file. If you call __import__ on a name after using import, you should get the same object because that resolution logic will detect the existing object in the import cache. If that doesn't happen, then you know the environment or arguments used by importutils when calling __import__ are wrong somehow.

>>> import sys
>>> s = __import__('sys')
>>> s is sys
True
>>>"}]

messages:
[{'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-06-14 02:39:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Yes, very helpful. This diagram is a good start, probably would do a lot to help people understand KVM v Xen if you show libvirt dotted line to Xen or XAPI - even I'm not sure of the relationship though I know it's run two different ways there are reasons for wanting one over another once you choose Xen/XenServer/XCP as your hypervisor."}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2012-06-14 14:03:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(2 inline comments)

Woaw, fantastic work Lorin. The schema is quite helpful. What the lines (full/ half) means ?'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-06-14 14:28:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

Anne: 

Because you normally wouldn't run KVM and Xen at the same time, I don't think it makes sense to show them both in the same diagram. What I think I will do instead is show two diagrams to show two possible instantiations, one with one set of technologies (KVM, RabbitMQ, IET, Apache) and the other with another set of technologies (Xen, Qpid, TGT, Nginx..), hopefully that will capture it.

Razique:

The dotted lines are meant to show interaction between two non-OpenStack software technologies. I'll add some text to explain this."}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-06-15 14:51:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Sounds right, Lorin, thanks for doing this!'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-06-16 23:50:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 612, 'date': '2012-06-17 00:16:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Document underlying technologies

This is a first attempt to give the reader a sense of what the underlying
technologies are behind OpenStack Compute.

Shows two possible configurations, as well as a table with supported
technologies.

Comments welcome, especially if there are any inaccuracies or unclear
concepts. It was difficult to try to capture the interactions between
these technologies, especially on the networking side.

Change-Id: Ib66e9c5b7c27b214b2b363d78f872ff5357b1619

commit_message:
Cisco plugin CLI call to quantumclient CLI

when Cisco plugin CLI is used, it wil call the quantumclient CLI if the command is not in its extensions.
the version of the Quantum API must be specified when the the Cisco plugin CLI is looking for Quantum commands.

Bug 1000251

Change-Id: I3e4039edb7cb79411fc60677ef6f99fca8007dc9

commit_message:
return 404 for invalid api version request

fixes bug: 934115

This fix returns 404 for all non-root requests that route via the
versions app. For root requests ('/') the available api version info is
returned.

Change-Id: I701389d9239cb40426f7a47206642b56c7eeeae1

commit_message:
Auto generate AUTHORS file for python-cinderclient component.

Bug: 976267

Now that git commits are gated by CLA, we shouldn't enforce
committers to add an entry in AUTHORS file. The AUTHORS file
should be generated automatically, based on git commits.

This commit fixes the problem.

* AUTHORS
  Remove this file.

* .gitignore
  Add AUTHORS file.

* cinderclient/shell.py
  pep8 fix.

Change-Id: I4e3c4524fc71a11f11b48fcb6abb99e6c7f33e90

commit_message:
Suppress pagination on non-tty glance index.

Fixes bug 978610.

Avoid the 'Fetch next page? [Y/n]' prompt interfering with
redirected output.

The native glance CLI will soon be superceeded by the new
python-glanceclient, however this patch could still be useful
to propogate from master to the stable diablo/essex branches.

Change-Id: I16bc6156d7c7e9ed27aabcaa51211060ec24a824

commit_message:
Adds property to selectively enable image caching.

The image-property `cache_in_nova` can be used to choose which images
should be cached in Nova. One use-case would be to cache base images but
not any customer snapshots.

Change-Id: I1b8ac914a6effd4cd4653aae7e4eac9d14d0e7bd

commit_message:
Fix pep8 errors w/pep8==1.3.

Also lock down the version of pep8 in
tools/test-requires. python-swiftclient had a passing test suite
yesterday, but today a new and stricter version of pep8 came out, and
the test suite started to fail. Specifying a particular version of
pep8 will prevent that.

Change-Id: I9092d2225c01b99158229918c86b185cdac9d362

commit_message:
Cleanup instance_update so it only takes a UUID.

You know when you try to do something simple like tweak
instance_update and instance_update_and_get_original and
it turns out to have all these knock on effects? Yeah,
that.

I still think this is a good idea though. I'd like to live
in a future where we don't have instance ids at all at the
DB API level. We need to do this to get there.

Change-Id: Ia51d06beaec068a8544642a6a4bf489247ff61a0

subject: Add libvirt min version check.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 24, 'name': 'Chuck Short', 'email': 'charles.short@windriver.com', 'username': 'zulcss'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 191, 'name': 'Trey Morris', 'email': 'trey.morris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'tr3buchet'}, {'_account_id': 357, 'name': 'Devin Carlen', 'email': 'devin@openstack.org', 'username': 'devcamcar'}, {'_account_id': 360, 'name': 'Dan Prince', 'email': 'dprince@redhat.com', 'username': 'dan-prince'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1779, 'name': 'Daniel Berrange', 'email': 'berrange@redhat.com', 'username': 'berrange'}, {'_account_id': 1812, 'name': 'p-draigbrady', 'email': 'P@draigBrady.com', 'username': 'p-draigbrady'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2271, 'name': 'Michael Still', 'email': 'mikal@stillhq.com', 'username': 'mikalstill'}, {'_account_id': 2750, 'name': 'Sean Dague', 'email': 'sean@dague.net', 'username': 'sdague'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-13 14:25:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/2980/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/4382/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/584/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/592/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/5081/ : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-06-13 15:00:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

More informative logs. good.

An alternative approach could be to support older versions by keying the new functionality on libvirt version.
That might be more appropriate for a distro patch though?'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-06-13 15:30:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

p-draigbrady,

Key'ing new functionality or API extensions on the libvirt version might be Okay. This check is more to guard against core OpenStack API functionality which won't work if the minimum version check isn't met.

Also, I kind of feel like if we start keying new functionality off of the libvirt version we might get into a free-for-all "lets always make use of the latest libvirt features" mindeset when in reality it is probably best to be a bit more disciplined about bumping the libvirt minimum version requirement.'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-06-13 16:04:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

Yes most NB point is to carefully consider dependencies,
and not blindly require the latest.

Also keying on version is dangerous as it doesn't consider backported features. For example Fedora 16 will currently log an error with its 0.9.6 version, though it might have had the feature backported (prob not, but still).
So in general, version checks are best done at the packaging level."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-06-13 16:44:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

While it is true that you can get into difficultly with cases where distro vendors have backported features, I think this is rare enough for us not to worry about. Also the RPM (or equiv) level version dependencies are not necessarily sufficient on their own, because libvirt is an RPC based system. The RPM version check will only enforce that the nova python client has the right libvirt version. What Dan's patch is doing is ensuring that the libvirtd daemon connection we have open is of a sufficiently new version.

Personally I feel this version check is worthwhile to avoid users deploying a system they think is working correctly, only to find random runtime exceptions thrown all over the place when they hit functionality not supported by the libvirt they connected to."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-06-13 21:24:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

While it definitely seems good to have a min version, perhaps we should fix hard_reboot to destroy and recreate if we are on an older version rather than forcing 9.7?

Vish'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-13 22:02:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

If we can do what Vish suggests, that'd be awesome, but no reason not to add the version check in any case

Minor issue inline"}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-06-13 22:36:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I agree with mark about the version log. Inexplicit tear down and recreate as a result of issuing a hard reboot sounds really bad to me. Am I missing something?"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-06-13 22:40:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Trey: it is the way we used to do reboots before they added reset. It doesn't tear down anything important, it would just do a libvirt.destroy() followed by a libvirt.create() which is how we did it before reset() was available. The domain definition and all networking setup would remain."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-06-14 16:28:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-06-14 16:45:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-06-14 19:14:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2012-06-14 20:14:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

While I agree with this in principal I think you are going to be limiting your users who dont want to upgrade to the latest and greatest Ubuntu/Fedora and want to still use their "hardy" ubuntu release.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-06-15 01:17:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Chuck:

To fully support Nova Folsom today you would need at least Libvirt 0.9.7. This patchset doesn't modify or change that fact. If you don't have it you'll get some rather cryptic errors in the log file when you try some API operations (like reboot for example). The idea here is simply that we should warn users as soon as possible in the config file when Libvirt is too old to support Nova.

Based on the comments in this changeset I think we agree that:

1) We are probably going to revert some of the recent changes which used newer Libvirt calls (thus allowing us to require an earlier version).

2) That having a min version check is still a good idea... we'll just need to figure out what the lower version actually is once we back out some of the 0.9.7 calls."}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2012-06-15 02:35:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

lgtm thanks for answering my questions.'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-06-15 06:31:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-06-15 19:42:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-15 21:13:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Starting gate jobs.'}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2012-06-15 21:13:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-15 21:26:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/3090/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/4489/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/691/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/699/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/5364/ : SUCCESS

commit_message:
Remove double quotes from nova.conf options reference

Using double quotes in nova.conf can seriously mess up Nova in
all sorts of ways. Remove their erroneous use from the config
documentation, and also emphasize that using them is a bad idea.

bug 1009974

Change-Id: I6b8423739ce19e7dd9ab426ea70bc8c330b2455a

commit_message:
Move docs to doc.

To better facilitate the building and publishing of sphinx
documentation by Jenkins we are moving all openstack projects with
sphinx documentation to a common doc tree structure. Documentation
goes in project/doc and build results go in project/doc/build.

Change-Id: I3ae14ac735d9b4c0b534eac9a9c142f8ccaac1b9

Scott, you can remove the footnote [1] :) Simply put the following as your commit message:

 Separate Metadata logic away from the web service

 partially implements bp config-drive-v2

 I wanted to separate out the "Metadata" from the
"Metadata Server". Thus, the creation of nova/api/metadata/base.py.

 The InstanceMetadata in base.py contains most of the logic for presenting metadata. As a result, the Metadata webservice in handler.py greatly simplified. This should make it easier to render duplicate data to a config drive.

 Additional changes here:
 * a few more tests
 * removal of the separate 'Versions' handler. Its now replaced by the single handler.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-06-05 23:58:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

Some nice cleanups in here, Scott. Few nits inline to look into, nothing major."}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2012-06-06 13:29:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-06 13:42:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/349/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/357/ : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/4583/ : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-06-06 17:45:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Looks like a good start.

I assume the following would be called/dumped on a config drive? (When that gets worked out, ie how to make that config drive and such)

def get_ec2_metadata_all(self):
    ...

Just some other thoughts:

Are there any differences between the versions that actually affect what content is available? Ie x field only is allowed in version y > z? Does it make sense to have some type of filter that gets called for a version that does this kind of reformatting and or removal of fields? This might make sense (at least to have a simple formatter per version to handle the differences that have occurred or will occur in the future?). Just right now it seems like there is validation on the versions, but all versions behave the same once that validation passes.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2012-06-06 17:51:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

In linesss.'}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2012-06-06 20:04:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I assume the following would be called/dumped on a config drive? (When that
> gets worked out, ie how to make that config drive and such)
>    def get_ec2_metadata_all(self):
> ...

Right, thats why it is in there.
I think that for config_drive I'll add a method to that like:
  render_to_filesystem_path() 

that would just do the dumping itself.

> Just some other thoughts:
> 
> Are there any differences between the versions that actually affect what
> content is available? Ie x field only is allowed in version y > z? Does it

In EC2, yes.  In Openstack's EC2 lookalike, no.  I put some more information about what the EC2 metadtaa looks like at http://paste.ubuntu.com/1027440/

> make sense to have some type of filter that gets called for a version that
> does this kind of reformatting and or removal of fields? This might make

Yeah, if we need to get fancier on that, I figured the right way is to have a Ec2MetaDataVersionYYYYMMDD and those inherit from a base class.  Then, get that object... This is really just keeping the status quo for now.

Additionally, my plan is to add a top level entry like 'openstack' to the versions (possibly even hidden in the indexing) that would have openstack specific metadata."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-06 20:17:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(14 inline comments)

Nice work Scott, good to see this getting cleaned up

This isn't a full review, but I guess there's a few things I've picked out:

1) style nitpicks

2) unused code - you probably use this code in a follow-on config drive patch, but I'd much prefer if the config drive patch added that code rather than adding unused code now

3) the InstanceMetadata class - not convinced this is needed. At most I'd add a dict specialization which has a lookup() method, but the dict population itself can just be a module-level method"}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2012-06-06 21:08:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-06-06 21:21:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Addresses my first 2 comments. From IRC, I think Scott agrees with (3), so I guess that's coming later"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-06 21:21:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

[{'created': '2012-06-04 16:04:38.000000000', 'message': 'separate Metadata logic away from the web service

The changes here are coming as a result of starting to implement
config-drive-v2 [1].  I wanted to separate out the "Metadata" from the
"Metadata Server".  Thus, the creation of nova/api/metadata/base.py.

The InstanceMetadata in base.py contains most of the logic for
presenting metadata.  As a result, the Metadata webservice in handler.py
greatly simplified.  This should make it easier to render duplicate
data to a config drive.

Additional changes here:
 * a few more tests
 * removal of the separate 'Versions' handler.  Its now replaced
   by the single handler.

--
[1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/config-drive-v2

presenting metadata.  As a result, the Metadata webservice in handler.py
greatly simplified.  This should make it easier to render duplicate
data to a config drive.

Additional changes here:
 * a few more tests
 * removal of the separate 'Versions' handler.  Its now replaced
   by the single handler.

Change-Id: I35fcfd8d7f247763954afc0a9f752f629b243e9b
'}]
commit_message:
separate Metadata logic away from the web service

The changes here are coming as a result of starting on blueprint
config-drive-v2 [1].  I wanted to separate out the "Metadata" from the
"Metadata Server".  Thus, the creation of nova/api/metadata/base.py.

The InstanceMetadata in base.py contains most of the logic for
presenting metadata.  As a result, the Metadata webservice in handler.py
greatly simplified.  This should make it easier to render duplicate
data to a config drive.

Additional changes here:
 * a few more tests
 * removal of the separate 'Versions' handler.  Its now replaced
   by the single handler.

Change-Id: I35fcfd8d7f247763954afc0a9f752f629b243e9b

[{'created': '2012-05-30 23:29:14.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Fix nova-manage backend_add with sr_uuid"

Fixes bug 988596

Change 77495cfe breaks storage manager, as it makes a
wrong assumption about nova-manage. The sr-uuid must be
generated and provided by the xenapi storage manager.

When the volume service is started, SM volume driver will
create a new SR for everything that does not have an
existing sr_uuid and will populate the db with the result.
It will only introduce the SRs that do have one. The introduce
will work only if the uuid provided is something SM understands.

This partially reverts commit 77495cfed17f12f225e11fbc10e0f8db516dadf2.
Changes in db are left intact.

commit_message:
Revert "Fix nova-manage backend_add with sr_uuid"

Fixes bug 988596

Change 77495cfe breaks storage manager, as it makes a
wrong assumption about nova-manage. The sr-uuid must be
generated and provided by the xenapi storage manager.

When the volume service is started, SM volume driver will
create a new SR for everything that does not have an
existing sr_uuid and will populate the db with the result.
It will only introduce the SRs that do have one. The introduce
will work only if the uuid provided is something SM understands.

This partially reverts commit 77495cfed17f12f225e11fbc10e0f8db516dadf2.
Changes in db are left intact.

Change-Id: I8405ac905a15f829f704951b94297f3b6f6c0a29

commit_message:
Fix stable/essex (2012.1.1) versioning

Fix stable/essex branch versioning that should have been set to 2012.1.1
when the branch was first used (with FINAL=False). FINAL should be set
to True when we want to cut the stable branch release.

Change-Id: Iea07571b7b9175db1176ce629e325ee95947d8e8

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-15 10:10:08.000000000', 'message': 'Kill glance-api child workers on SIGINT

Fixes bug 978130

Previously glance-api configured to run multiple child
workers went in a respawn tail-spin when the parent is
interrupted with crtl+c.

This is now avoided by terminating the process group when
SIGINT is received, in the same way as SIGTERM is handled.

Change-Id: Ieca90f45e07cc3645a997bba493e0b9a9f08a470
'}]
commit_message:
Kill glance-api child workers on SIGINT

Fixes bug 978130

Previously glance-api configured to run multiple child
workers went in a respawn tail-spin when the parent is
interrupted with crtl+c.

This is now avoided by terminating the process group when
SIGINT is received, in the same way as SIGTERM is handled.

Change-Id: Ieca90f45e07cc3645a997bba493e0b9a9f08a470

commit_message:
Fix to not use deprecated response.environ any more.

WebOb 1.2 doesn't auto-set the response environment. There was only one place
in Glance that was using this, so it was changed in favor of the stable API
that has always been there: response.request.environ.

This change fixes bug #1010560.

Change-Id: I2e58bf32970c95d25cad0a35ee38b9540483eef0

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-15 13:25:02.000000000', 'message': '012_id_to_uuid: Also convert ramdisk + kernel ids

The original migration converts numerical IDs to UUIDs.  It updates
image_members and image_properties that reference image_id, but stops
short of updating actual properties that reference the new UUIDs,
specifically kernel_ids and ramdisk_ids.  This breaks launching
of instances in Nova whos images are associated with a kernel and/or rd.

Also, this fixes an issue when migrating against non-sqlite
databases where the actual conversion is executed twice.

Fixes bug 975655
Fixes bug 975651

Update: Only update kernel_ids and ramdisk_ids in image_properties
        when converting to UUIDs

Change-Id: I76ecabc5ee266e2e9765740721e8ec1722cc5a7c
'}]
commit_message:
012_id_to_uuid: Also convert ramdisk + kernel ids

The original migration converts numerical IDs to UUIDs.  It updates
image_members and image_properties that reference image_id, but stops
short of updating actual properties that reference the new UUIDs,
specifically kernel_ids and ramdisk_ids.  This breaks launching
of instances in Nova whos images are associated with a kernel and/or rd.

Also, this fixes an issue when migrating against non-sqlite
databases where the actual conversion is executed twice.

Fixes bug 975655
Fixes bug 975651

Update: Only update kernel_ids and ramdisk_ids in image_properties
        when converting to UUIDs

Change-Id: I76ecabc5ee266e2e9765740721e8ec1722cc5a7c

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-11 13:46:11.000000000', 'message': "Don't query nova-network on startup.

Backport from commit 8db54f3.
Fix bug 999698.

nova-compute requested network info for each instance on startup via rpc.
If all services get (re)started at the same time, nova-network may not
be available to take this request, resulting in a lost request.  To
combat this issue, get the network info from the cache in the database
on startup.  If by some chance this information is not correct, it will
get fixed up by a periodic task.

Change-Id: Ifb0634e87770f565e4ab36a54f6e9e19e5f31632
"}, {'created': '2012-06-15 12:44:51.000000000', 'message': "Don't query nova-network on startup.

Backport from commit 8db54f3.
Fix bug 999698.

nova-compute requested network info for each instance on startup via rpc.
If all services get (re)started at the same time, nova-network may not
be available to take this request, resulting in a lost request.  To
combat this issue, get the network info from the cache in the database
on startup.  If by some chance this information is not correct, it will
get fixed up by a periodic task.

Change-Id: Ifb0634e87770f565e4ab36a54f6e9e19e5f31632
"}]
commit_message:
Don't query nova-network on startup.

Backport from commit 8db54f3.
Fix bug 999698.

nova-compute requested network info for each instance on startup via rpc.
If all services get (re)started at the same time, nova-network may not
be available to take this request, resulting in a lost request.  To
combat this issue, get the network info from the cache in the database
on startup.  If by some chance this information is not correct, it will
get fixed up by a periodic task.

Change-Id: Ifb0634e87770f565e4ab36a54f6e9e19e5f31632

commit_message:
Add missing ack to impl_qpid.

Fix bug 1012374.

Johannes Erdfelt pointed out that impl_qpid wasn't acking messages that
it received.  This turned out to be a nasty oversight, resulting in
unbounded message queue growth inside of the python-qpid library.  This
fixes it.

Change-Id: I0370293807f0282e1dbdd59246f70be031e888a9
(cherry picked from commit d15f3034dfab05ef0ec02b4e353b3dfa1512db35)

commit_message:
Add missing ack to impl_qpid.

Fix bug 1012374.

Johannes Erdfelt pointed out that impl_qpid wasn't acking messages that
it received.  This turned out to be a nasty oversight, resulting in
unbounded message queue growth inside of the python-qpid library.  This
fixes it.

Change-Id: I446530239e16701009c4db8407a344596bb17952
